This is a great game that I enjoy. It is easy to recommend as it is one of those games that understands that difficulty should be up to the player. 

This is a result of not only the many game options, but also due to the selection of mod offerings. For example, if you just want a casual game to travel around you can have driving assists on, fines disabled, and automatic parking of trailers at your destination. This way it is not too stressful. Or you could have it to be where money is easy to make, but the challange comes from turning all the driving assists off and letting the driving itself be the challange. Then there is the way I play, with driving assists on, but economy mod to make earning money a lot more difficult while keeping fines. This makes the challange really be all about the money and puts me in a situation where one mistake during a drive could cause me to loose money as the expenses will be more than I was paid. Wheras the base game pays you enough money that even with a couple fines or a crash you can still gain money from a delivery. 

There is no real wrong way to play and the game understands that. It does require mods and the like to be the same for multipler which is fine, but the versitility is what makes it great. 

Other great aspects of the game have been discussed elsewhere, but I just wanted to focus on how much I love the fact that difficulty is up to the player, which, in turn, makes it more fun. I love it when games let me decide where my challange comes from, and I love that challange being the money making and balancing, while I have no interest in having real life physics applying to my load or realistic braking. I am fine with having to park trailer myself, but none of that fluids in tanks shifting while driving stuff. If you disagree then you can play your way and have fun with your preferred challange.

Embarking on a fresh adventure in TruckSim feels incredibly authentic, allowing for personal growth and development. I am currently navigating this journey with my loyal companion, Peanut, by my side. As the saying goes, "There's more to us than meets the eye." Together, we are two brothers seamlessly rising to the challenge.
pretty good game.

It's not a complex as some of you are thinking. Mouse and keyboard is all you need to have a great time running trucks around the western US. Mods are simple to use and make everything that much funner and fantastic.

Sure, the cities aren't a one-to-one model of the real ones, but driving through the cities I actually do know had me surprisingly amazed at how accurate they are within the limits of the scale of the game.  I passed through San Antonio, TX and chuckled at seeing so many landmarks I know so well from the freeway.  I took the freeway up to DFW and saw so many landmarks that are quite familiar to me from that drive.  The game is relaxing, as easy or difficult as you want it to be, and while it may not be a 100% perfect translation of driving a big rig, it's enough to keep you wanting to explore all of the gorgeous terrain available to you.  It's definitely a game for hobbyists.

This simulator is pretty fun and relaxing to play. There are a couple traffic things that could be improved, like exit ramps and new speed zones. Before exit rams, vehicles just come to a sudden 30 mph or so with no warning while still on highways or interstates. Same with new speed zones, traffic just goes from 60 to 45 in a split second with no gradual slow down. Then if possible, it would be cool to see the AI semi traffic using their hazards when going through construction zones.

A captivating and immersive driving experience that offers a realistic and nuanced handling. The game‚Äôs simulation is deep and the production values are higher than most sims, making it mysteriously compelling despite its mundane subject matter. The game is slow-paced, with the sudden appearance of a tumbleweed being genuinely thrilling. However, the game‚Äôs size is its main drawback, as it feels more like a foundation than a full game. Despite this, the low price tag and addictive simulator gameplay make it a joy to go trucking through famous cities.

This game makes me think of my late Grandfather. His name was Leon Lackey, he was a truck driver for 45 years in Northern California and he hauled mainly Gas Tankers for his career. He taught me everything that I know about driving period. Grandpa Leon used to always tell me stories about driving a big rig and the challenges that he experienced in the 60's and beyond. I would love for my Grandfather to be alive because even though he never liked technology, he would have loved to watch myself and others stream this game.

wish i could give this a so-so review, but i cannot so it gets a thumbs down. 2016 this game came out, still feels like a 2016 game. the base game on sale is like 6/7$cad and is just okay for that price. comes with California, great, the slowest, most unfinished state in the game. if you convince your friends to purchase this, which is difficult already (regular price is like 30$cad) . prepare them to spend 120-200$cad just on the current dlc's, BLOODY MADNESS (14-20$ per dlc wtf). 8 years since release and this is where we're at. the trucks don't gain one spec of dust or rust, i mean not even some bugs on the windshield, what??? cannot get out and walk around your rig, only in workshop adding upgrades you can walk around. since the addition of multiplayer 2-3 years ago, the modding community has kept this game alive and made it playable for multiplayer thru mods. without the community this game wouldn't be much, just a money grab. (graphics are bad! download a mod. biome's are empty! need mods so it isn't lifeless. basic simple truck upgrades like rims??? need a mod, or spend 5$ on a tire pack. but hey if you want a valentines livery for these lonely weirdo's playing, they got that) as for the die hard fans, for the most part are toxic and some weirdo's who spent more money on an in house steering wheel pedal setup instead of their mazda 3 or mortgage. this is bananas. the reason i have the hours i do is because my friend and i used to play it here and there doing long hauls, gets to a point we both fall asleep out of boredom. no animal life, no deer or elk running across the roads, just some road blockages that piss you off more than anything, you end up driving on the shoulder so you don't get to your delivery late. no snow, no seasons, cant chain up tires, cant even pop the hood to see the engines goddammit. euro truck is worse thank god i had some common sense at that point. childhood connection roots deep in this game as i grew up playing 18wheels of steel... this is the reskinned brother like MJ, and still the same fing liveries from however many years ago. mods can only fix so much. every few players who purchase these stupid dlc's are paying for an all inclusive trip to mexico for the lazy devs. don't feed into it! don't buy the dlc's! i have tried and tried again but this is not it unless you are a 50yrold lonely man who never got their class 1 trying to still live out that dream. real talk, buy snowrunner that is a real trucking game. watch this review get taken down. FREE TOP G. peace&love homies. spend the 200$ on your girl while you still have her because if she sees you playing this she outta there!

I downloaded the demo of this game thinking I'd enjoy it for a few weeks or months before moving onto something else. I'd generally play train simulators. But I'd had SCS Bus Driver years ago and thought I'd check out truck simulator. 750 hours of playing time I'm still here and enjoying the game as much as when I began. Things have certainly come a LONG way since Bus Driver. Lol! 
I'm usually disappointed by driving games with unrealistic roads, signs and markings etc. That definitely does not apply to American Truck Simulator. Even when I come across something odd that appears to be a mistake, I just check google streetview of the actual location and quickly discover, nope. That 'mistake' actually exists in the real location, and the game has faithfully copied it. I'm used to driving on the left, but that has not been an issue to me at all. I've even learnt of some interesting locations and attractions via the simulation that I had not known about before. So it's also been quite educational and shall be helpful if I ever get around to visiting the USA myself. Although I'd have to adjust to the time and distances being much greater in real life than they are in the game. :)

dfsgh

Spent six hours trying to configure hardware with no success.
Can't believe this game has been out there for at least 8 years and they don't even have alt or ctl combo key mappings.

NOTE: Steam refused refund because of 2 hour time limit.
I thought I had a day to try to get this to work. Never tried a refund before. 

I've purchased over $2000.00 worth of software from Steam over the years and this is the first time I couldn't get something to work.
Well that's what happens when there's no REGULATION in the industry.

Remember if you can't get this monstrosity to work in an hour and a half STOP trying and get your refund!!!! DO NOT BUY any DLC unless you can get the main program working.

It's like the game was written for a $400.00 piece of hardware and nothing else.
ie. 
1. I have two thrustmaster 1600 joysticks. Each has like 14 buttons and I'm not allowed to manually shift gears unless I have this $400.00 H-Shifter

2. I've driven truck over the road several years in my youth. I've never seen where air pressure is low when you have no damage unless you forget to hook up your hoses. These must be trucks built in Russia with very bad air compressors when they run out of air after pressing the brake twice.

3. Whether I'm steering with joystick or MS controller the steering is way over kill like no one ever balanced the tires. Very similar to the retarded spaceship steering in Starfield. Rubber band like is the best way I can describe it. You can never do just a small amount of correction.

4. Even went to the point of uninstalling all Logitech software with no success. Keyboard simply refuses to work with two thrustmasters. Who knows maybe it's still the Steam controller software. Maybe it's NVidia. Maybe it's Logitech. Maybe it's Microsoft....yada yada yada.

5. After doing a lot of reading on the net even people who buy the $400.00 unit still have problems.

4. Had to constantly start game over many times. Never got past first tutorial run. Whenever I'd try to change something the $300,000 brand new truck would always run out of air. Or get locked in reverse because of some confusion between the old keyboard setting and the new joystick "wizard" setting.

Unfortunate. I've read a lot of good things about this game. All I can suggest is pay the $10.00 sale price, DON'T buy any DLC until you  try it on your computer if it doesn't work chalk it off as loss. Don't waste any time trying to configure it unless you already have the $400.00 H-Shifter wooooooo. REMEMBER you only have 1 1/2 hours to get this monstrosity to work.

All I got for $35.00 was a red face and high blood pressure.

[h1]An amazing game that is suitable for every audience.[/h1]

The game has an amazing feeling to it, a therapeutic feeling, and this [i]really[/i] makes the game stand out. Although it hass no story and at first glance looks like a game that would be boring, this game is completely the opposite. It features a sense of accomplishment aswell; when you get a new truck or a new garage, you feel a sense of pride and great satisfaction. [b]Definetely recommend. 10/10.[/b] I would also recommend ETS2. You can find my review of that game on my profile.

Hey Steam users!
ATS provides you a truly immersive journey into the world of trucking.The attention to detail in recreating iconic American landscapes is astounding,offering a visually stunning backdrop for your hauls.The realistic driving mechanics, coupled with a wide array of trucks and cargo, create a satisfyingly authentic experience.Whether you're a trucking enthusiast or a ''newbie'' in the truck world, ATS offers a unique and enjoyable simulation of the open road.The variety of trucks and cargo, coupled with a sense of freedom on the open road.
I hope Latin American countries appear in the future DLCs or in the another game. *fingers crossed*

I love the game.  The trucks, the roads, and the scenery are very good.  This is a very relaxing game which I didn't think was possible with a driving game.   I love the new content that is released makes the game more exciting to play. I don't mind paying for something that will last and is very good quality.

Forget about the grind, American Truck Simulator is all about the green. My truck may be digital, but my cargo is definitely organic. The best part? No drug tests required in the virtual trucking industry. Blaze a trail on the open road and let the good times roll... literally.
good game
cool beans

I know nothing about trucks, I hate driving long distances in real life. This game is like an escape from reality, I just put on some black metal and drive, it's soooooooo relaxing. I added a bunch of mods to the game and use reshade to make the game look pretty hot. This game really was not designed to be an open world racing sim, but I just speed around in a lambo, the physics are funny as fuck because of this. I have the g29 racing wheel and a button box, works flawlessly.

Even with a ton of mods, I don't think I've ever encountered any kind of game breaking bug. The game is not ugly, but it doesn't use ultra complex shaders so it's extremely stable, even at high resolutions and with upscaling. Low end systems can run this, and high end systems can add graphics mods if desired. I love this game so much.

I've purchased every state dlc (which are reasonably priced), because the game is THAT FUN. and I've also bought Euro Truck Simulator 2 and all the area DLC's as well. I really love the attention to detail of the developer. The scale of their games are huge.

I'm still a rank beginner, and new to sims like this.  Heck this is the only modern sim I have right now.  I haven't played "video games" in years.  I got this on a sale just to try it out... and I am glad I did.  It's a bit daunting at first, but the learning curve isn't too steep and the driving is pretty fun.  It's not crazy racing - it's relaxing but requires concentration.  It's casual but you're building a serious business.  It's beautiful, but be careful taking your eyes off the road.  I haven't scratched the surface yet, and I look forward to trying all the different things available!   I know it's a game I will keep coming back to.  Well done!

To call this a simulation is like saying Fiat is just as good as Ferrari, because they are both Italian and have wheels.

Your driver is a picture
You have no visible hands
You can never leave the cabin
You need to sleep, but not eat
Your company drivers are pictures
You can not put your company name on your trucks
And you never see your company trucks on the road
You can not hire who you like when you like, as the driver pool rotate
You can not buy what you want when you want, as it is level locked
All the trucks are old. Even the "new" trucks are NOS (new old stock)
You can not drive a rigid, dump, box car or pick up trucks
There are no exhaust smoke, visible damage or dirt
You ALWAYS get stopped at customs
The GPS is in dire need of updating
The economy is broken
Weight limits are broken
Physics are very broken
The AI is severely broken and the list goes on and on and on.

The game is in many ways a joke, but it does have some redeeming features, so the negativity is actually for the greedy developers that really are a joke and not the game itself.

The base game is as bare bones as possible so they can sell a DLC for every little thing, such as a flag in your window, a paint job, new tires, complete Steam achievements and of course a new map. 

ETS 2 have 4 complete and 2 partial countries out of the 44 that is Europe in the base game.
The rest is only available if you give them your credit card.
ATS only have 3 of the 50 states and every DLC for a state / country cost more than the game
It does not help that there are over 100 of them available for both games, and every time they get less content and worse quality.
Or when the Ukraine war started they heavily promoted the Ukrainian skin pack, and put the Heart of Russia DLC that was scheduled to come on indefinite hold.
It does not help that there are no real life brands in the game to avoid paying for copyrights, but there are real life advertisements, since SCS get paid to put them in either.
Or that every state / country are made from the same copy / pasted roads, buildings and scenery, rearranged to look more similar to what ever place they are making, with some newly made street signs and a couple of non copyrighted landmarks before they call it a day
Or that the most famous landmarks such as the Eiffel tower are missing.

"Those landmarks are not included by design. It was a hard decision, made as a result of due to discussing that case in details in past, especially while creating previous DLC Vive La France, where as you may notice, there is Eiffel Tower not included.
As the game includes "Truck" in the name, we made the decision, to show the city from truck driver perspective. Trucks are not allowed to enter city centers, and mentioned landmarks are neither super high nor located on the hills, to be visible from industrial areas. So that they are not visible in the game." piotr  [developer] Posted: 6 Dec, 2017

If that is true, why is it only copyrighted landmarks that are not included ?

SCS is NOT a small indie company either as some like you to believe. 
They have 400 employees and had over 50 million USD in assets and 13 million USD in net income in 2019.
They are just another greedy company that even EA would be proud of.


However 

Even though it is not a simulator, you can drive for hours upon hours without interruptions.
That part is absolutely superb.
It also serves as a good base for mods, and there are a lot of insanely talented mod makers out there making it a great driving game instead of some mediocre money grabbing machine.

For free.

So if you want a American Truck Driving game with events and fun and keeps you wanting come back this is definitely the game you should get you won't have any regrets about it.

It gets boring and monotonous after a bit, but that's why I love it. No real thought process needed, just log-in and go from where you left off. 
 You can buy garages, upgrade them to accommodate more trucks, buy trucks and trailers, hire drivers. Rinse and repeat. Sooner or later, during or after each trip you take, you'll be banking so much $$$ you can buy/upgrade a garage or two, fill it it with brand new trucks and trailers, hire the drivers, and still have money to burn. 
 Then came the mods:
There are a sh*t ton of mods in the workshop, ranging from paint jobs to engines, transmissions, sounds, weather, and even realism mods. Yes, there are xp and $$$ mods as well.
 The bad/ downside: (I do understand they need to make money,but...)
They will nickle and dime you for just about everything. So it's best to wait for when there is a steam sale before picking up the desired dlc's. Sales happen often, so make sure you check out the bundled options on the sale page. 
 I also wish they would come out with a map pack that had multiple new states, instead of just one at a time. Such as a midwest map pack, east coast, the 'south'. Based off the size of the states on the upper east coast, I can see them releasing multiple states as one pack in this situation. 
 But all in all, they get an A in my book. If you've played previous titles, this will be a good one to get into.

The graphics are great now, the map is amazing and road updates are crazy. Hopefully they will add more realism to the game that can be enabled or disabled in the settings. I really want to be able to practice backing up a front trailer with a dolly linking with the rear, live sliding tandems at weigh stations or after missions start and you have to view the weight to make changes. if you can change the weather, traffic, an interior details of this game then i cant imagine it would be hard to involve more mechanics on trucks in the settings to have more realism for certain players.

Im going to change this review to positive whenever in-game event log appears. Right now most of events require you to visit unique city in one of the states for each of your deliveries. And if you like me, dropping into the game once in a month or so just to relax a bit, you probably wont be able to complete those stupid events because there is NO IN-GAME WAY TO track the cities you already delivered to.  

"Akchually, tfere is a wfay, kjust withit khe web-site"-

What website? Am I playing a browser game or what? Are you going to force me to use external resource to track my progress? Those events are happening in ATS, a game that you launch from Steam, I couldnt be bothered to pull up a browser because of dev's unwillingless to make an in-game tracker of some sort. 

But okay, maybe im bit lazy, maybe I just eat it up and track my progress by looking at the log on my WoT profile...

It only shows last 25 contracts you completed. Thats it. 

Go pull up a notepad or something, ctrl f the cities you already completed and cross them off the list.

Whats that? You are not playing English version and you cant recognise names of the citries at a glance? You dont even know what cities belongs to each state because WoT doesnt show it for some reason? What are you, not living in US or something, why you are even playing AMERICAN simulator?

And another thing - since later states are pretty small I found myself in pretty stupid situation where most of the cities are marked as visited since I drive trought towns anyway. I have no way to track my progress via WoT because it only shows several last deliveries which are flooded with christmas contracts and just random deliveres I decided to do. This leaves me with no way to finish said event in time because Ill need to check EACH INDIVIDUAL CITY IN KANSAS by delivering a cargo from it and seeing if the game recongised it as unique delivery or not. Thats such disrespect for player's time that Im not ever going to be bothered to complete any events until some sort of tracking is implemented. Im already busy with being an adult, okay?..

This game is absolutely PHENOMENAL. It's everything you want it to be, and it delivers. It's SO fun to drive and I love this game so much, the developers are working constantly adding new map DLCs and new DLC customization packs, and it's insane, the developer team literally visits REAL LIFE states for analysis on how they can build their map. It's simply outstanding what a game company is willing to do for their game. American Truck Simulator is one of the best games on Steam and has been one of the best since release.

I HIGHLY recommend anyone to play this game, you will fall in love with the sounds, the atmosphere, the trucks, and the customization options that this game has for the trucks. Not to mention the IN-BUILT wheel support, that is simply amazing.

The mods that people create for American Truck Simulator also enhance the feel and overall structure of this game, and it's nothing short of amazing. An absolute 10/10 (maybe even an 11/10) for ATS. It is just a fantastic game!

As a retired UPS driver, this game is the best. I started sim racing/flight in the 90's and this to me is the cats meow. At UPS we didn't have air horns , or jake brakes, so I get to enjoy using them now.. I own a Meta Quest 3 and highly recommend VR, along with a direct drive wheel base and 330mm wheel, Buttkicker Pro, z906 surround sound, Fanatec cs shifter and solid racing cockpit. I have the clutch unassigned and float every gear even reverse and drive everything manually even the automatics. The mods are incredible. AI old cars, motorcycles, real companies, gas stations, truck and trailer skins galore etc. I own/drive cars also such as Lambo Countach, Mercedes Benz, Escalade, Hellcat ect. I always go for difficult trailer staging as my experience is top level. I caught a winter sale and bought all the DLC's. Morgan Freeman is my navigation voice.

I love American Truck Simulator!
Supposedly, it is always the first sentence that matters if you manage to get the reader interested and if they read the review. I hope I succeeded, because I didn't make up my love for this game for myself at all.

I've been getting together to write this review for a very, very, very, very long time. There are so many things I want to write here that I don't know if I can do it. It will probably be very chaotic, but what the heck.

If you are reading this review, then:
1) You love ATS as much as I do and as much as thousands of other people do, and you want to read what others have to say about it;
2) You are thinking about buying this game, but don't know if it's worth it;
3) You want to know how ATS compares to ETS and what the differences are;
4) You just want to read reviews.
And I will be happy to try to address all points here! :-)

Everyone who is at least a little bit in the world of simulators and who has at least once interacted with Euro Truck Simulator 2 or heard of SCS has probably heard of ATS. It is the little brother of ETS. Younger and... better (this is important: in my opinion).

The game allows us to take on the role of a truck driver and tour American states. As a driver, we perform orders and earn money. After earning enough cash, we have the opportunity to buy our truck, spruce it up in our own way, hire workers and perform more orders.
But what, in my opinion, makes the game so very special? CLIMATE! A climate that even pours out of the monitor screen.
Driving along the European routes in Euro Truck Simulator 2, I felt a sense of weariness and boredom as the twentieth minute passed and I drove along the same highway and looked at the same sights for twenty minutes only to enter one of the European cities, which, however, did not resemble a city, as it was a maximum of three cross streets and a few buildings.
You can feel the progress in ATS. You can feel that it is a new game. You can feel that SCS has put a lot of effort into this game. You can feel that the developers wanted changes and those changes were delivered to us.
There is no question of getting tired of the views.A great influence is the fact that the states are compared to any country in ETS 2.So once we drive through deserts, go downhill, pass villages, then enter a forest, drive out across the ocean to enter a city (and by "cities" I mean a big, impressive city - colorful, full of banners, exits, streets, stores, buildings and cars) - zero time for boredom and weariness! Outside the cities, too, are full of scattered details and tidbits. The maps are not empty, they are not monotonous.


The game premiered on February 2, 2016 and did not have an easy start or an easy life. At the very beginning we received only two states. After some time, another one was added. In addition, the blackness was poured over by the fact that the map was very small. It was only after about a year that it was scaled up and got bigger. However, these stumbling blocks and shortcomings were necessary to get down to patching the game as soon as possible. And it has succeeded!.

As of today, the game offers 13 states California, Nevada, Arizona, New Mexico, Oregon, Washington, Utah, Idaho, Colorado, Montana,Wyoming, Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas. Another Nebraska, Arkansas,Missouri will be added
In the couple of years since its release, the game has received a lot of content, SCS Software has grown, and work on the game has accelerated.

ATS also beats ETS in the fact that it is fresher. Euro Truck Simulator 2 came out in 2012 and has a lot of places on the map that have been untouched, outdated, even ugly since then. ATS has no such places. There is nothing to improve in it. As I mentioned earlier, the maps are full of details. They are beautiful. And incredibly atmospheric!

The game also uses an improved proprietary SCS engine. This means that it is prettier and richer in detail than its European brother. What also follows is improved performance.

So much for the technicalities and differences between the two games.
If you are looking for a game where you can relax, forget about your problems or just calm down - this is the perfect title! Just choose an assignment, sit back and enjoy the views. You can drive in silence or turn on your favorite music and drive, drive, drive along the sunset.

You can also turn on one of the radio stations. For example, the one created by the community. The community is one of the greatest features of both games. In addition to the radio stations, the community watches over the modification of the multiplayer and the expansion of the maps. Unlike many, many games the community is really great and not to join us is a shame! :-)

ATS is my favorite game. It allows me to relax, calm down, feel like I'm in America, catch a glimpse of the culture, the sights, feel that vibe.

And this is just the beginning of the adventure! SCS has plans to complete the map with all states. Can't wait for that moment! :-) So if you've been wondering if it's worth it to start playing after such a long time, the answer is probably one:Yes! The real adventure is just beginning!

For gam I recommend a steering wheel. Logitech/29/g920. Impressions and sensations unearthly.also you can play. Keyboard + mouse 

The review should also end with something. Personally, I do not play multiplayer, but if you would like to have a friend with whom you can talk about the game, the next states that will appear in the game, share impressions, share a screen shot, loosely talk or just ask about the game itself - send me an invitation. I'll accept anyone!

I hope my review has convinced you that it's worth giving this game a chance and falling in love with it, getting behind the wheel of an American truck, accepting an assignment and setting off into the unknown. The beautiful unknown. And discover the yet undiscovered.

All you have to do is delete this local folder:
Steam\steamapps\common\Steam Controller Configs\xxxxx
then restart Steam

Of course SCS   has done an excellent job in replicating noteworthy trucking equipment, their handling and visual representation but to my surprise, they have created an outstanding environmental and ambiance that adds an immersive level that's missing in so many AAA games.. The highlights and noteworthy spots in depicted cities are a super touch. In game, I take a "vacation" and just drive around the maps to explore. Absolutely best and biggest time sink game that I have. One can drive conservatively ie IRL or make a run more attuned to a "Cannonball Run". The addons available are generally very high quality and are easy to enable or discard. I've played this game off and on for over five years and it just gets better and better. The SCS team and the huge ATS community are a fantastic combo.  Can't endorse it enough.

This game is extremely fun to play, but also grindy at the same time. If you have a wheel that is connected to your pc, definitely get this game if your prepared for spending money on dlc's. There are quite of bit of dlc's here, them not even finished the entire USA. Sad thing is you need to buy a dlc for 1 state, (maybe a bundle, which is about 2- 3). But, if you don't care about DLC's, this game is very fun! It is very realistic, and they took the time to make everything the exact same as real life, (especially the highways). If you have a wheel, sometimes the game will bug out a little bit when you first plug it in, so make sure you check the options and configuration settings once you have set the wheel in, don't immediately start a job. The game is about 25 GB big, so before you buy it make sure that your pc has enough space. The graphics are great and so is the game play, and it only requires a decent - good pc. Also, this game is verified on Steam Deck, so you can play this on steam deck which, is kind of cool actually. 9/10 game, not 10 out of 10 because you need a lot of patience to do long delivery's. (example Texas - California.) 9/10 definitely worth it for the price.

ATS is a joyride for simulation enthusiasts, offering a perfect blend of fun and realism. The game's attention to detail is impeccable, making you feel like you've traded your controller for a steering wheel. Customizing trucks adds a personal touch, turning your virtual ride into a roadworthy masterpiece. As you hit the highways, the immersive experience truly makes you believe you're a trucker navigating through the vast landscapes. Warning: Play responsibly, as it's easy to lose track of time while cruising the open roads, creating an addictive experience that'll have you hooked for hours on end.

This game is very very fun! ... Simply put, you're a truck driver,delivering your freight on short trips or long over the road hauls.  If you are the player that needs lots of fast action gaming,then skip this game...If you think you'd like traveling and seeing the country and all the beautiful scenery in a relaxing element,then this game is for you. Just keep your eyes on the road.  There are accidents (with police directing traffic)  Road construction and cars disabled or pulled over by police.  There are realistic traffic patterns with traffic lights and stop signs (better obey them or you get a ticket),and even animals and tumbleweeds blowing across the highway. And don't pass up those weigh stations or you will be fined. The truck setups are very realistic with turn signals,two speed wipers for rain,hazard lights,horns and you can even make seat adjustments. I've had a lot of fun playing this game when I just wanted to relax. This game lets you do that.  Try it,I think you'll like it if this is your type of game.

One of the first things that struck me about the American Truck Simulator is the attention to detail. Every aspect of this game is well-crafted from the stunning graphics to the realistic truck models. The landscapes and cities are also incredibly realistic, making me feel like im driving through different parts of America.

What sets American Truck Simulator apart from other trucking games is the level of customization it offers. You can customize your truck with different paint jobs, and accessories, and even upgrade its performance. This adds a personal touch to the game and allows me to create a truck that truly reflects my style.

American Truck Simulator is a captivating simulation game that immerses players into the world of long-haul trucking across the United States. Developed by SCS Software, the game offers a highly realistic driving experience with attention to detail in truck design and road environments.

Players begin their journey as truckers, starting with a basic truck and gradually building their empire by completing deliveries, earning money, and upgrading their vehicles. The game's attention to realism extends to its road network, weather conditions, and day-night cycles, providing a true-to-life experience.

One of the standout features is the meticulously recreated landscapes, including iconic American landmarks and cities. The game's graphics contribute to the immersive atmosphere, enhancing the sense of exploration as players traverse diverse terrains.

The variety of cargo and the dynamic economy add depth to the gameplay, offering challenges and opportunities for strategic decision-making. Moreover, the inclusion of a multiplayer mode allows players to connect with friends or fellow truckers in a cooperative online environment.

American Truck Simulator strikes a balance between realism and entertainment, making it a must-play for simulation enthusiasts and those seeking a unique journey across the vast landscapes of the United States.

American Truck Simulator (ATS) provides an immersive and realistic trucking experience that captivates players from the start. The attention to detail in recreating iconic American landscapes is commendable, making each journey a visual delight. The variety of trucks and customization options add depth to the gameplay, allowing players to personalize their virtual trucking experience.
American Truck Simulator stands out as a top-tier simulation game, and with a few enhancements in multiplayer functionality and gameplay variety, it has the potential to become an even more captivating virtual trucking journey.

The game's intuitive controls make it accessible to both seasoned truck sim enthusiasts and newcomers, creating a seamless and enjoyable gaming experience. The realistic physics and dynamic weather conditions further enhance the sense of immersion, making every drive feel like a genuine cross-country adventure.

In terms of future improvements, it would be fantastic to see expanded multiplayer features, enabling players to convoy with friends or other trucking enthusiasts. Additionally, introducing more diverse cargo types and challenges could add another layer of complexity and excitement to the gameplay. Improving AI interactions on the road and enhancing the overall traffic system would contribute to a more authentic simulation experience.

I recently picked up a Quest 3, and despite enjoying the likes of No Man's Sky & Skyrim (modded) in VR, American Truck Simulator has been the most fun & immersive. It's incredible just how well this translates to VR and it's breathed fresh air into Truck Sim for me.

It's more of a "simulation lite" unless you have the expensive gear (pedals, wheels, sticks, et al) to make it more. The UI is also very much what you'd expect on the computers of a trucking business lol. Nonetheless! It's like gathering in an MMO or "space trucking" in a space sim. It's chill. You just get the cargo, sit back, and drive. Particularly for the sale price, how can I dislike it? I do, however, wish that we had far more customization options. Particularly for the interiors, but perhaps this is the result of staying more genuine to what's actually available in these trucks. And hey, that's what mods are for.

Great game. Very relaxing to just play this and throw on some of your favourite tunes. If you liked ETS2, you'll very much enjoy this as well. Seems most of the difference is in maps and trucks. The trucks are bigger, and therefore a bit harder to use, but plays very much the same apart from that. Added features like adaptive cruise, blind spot warning, etc. The cities are gorgeous, very well made. I'm newer to ATS, but have played ETS2 for almost 200 hours. Never gets boring, surprisingly. A steal when on sale, a great game still at full price. You can't go wrong buying this game. The DLC is all beautiful, well designed. SCS is the GOAT.

1.3.2020 - 24 hours of play - The game is a ton of fun. It would be better if they would add more of the US than they have but it is slowly moving along since Washington, Oregon, California, New Mexico, and Arizona are in. What sucks is that they cost a lot each time you have to buy another state. It really should probably be two states for the price of the one currently. Regardless, it is a fun game.

1.15.2024 - 264 hours of play - So far everything I have asked for has been happening. More has been added. I bought most of the DLC packs for the game. About half of the US is added to the game at the time of this edited review. The packs don't seem to be as expensive as they were before (or at least they feel more worth it). I still recommend waiting for the packs to be on sale before buying unless you really just have to have the state released but I don't feel too bad about purchasing for full price anymore with how great the new maps look.

30 years since I drove OTR in many, many of the places depicted in this sim. Not "picture perfect" but many things are close enough to revive old memories of driving thru the actual place. Hilarious part, the AI 'driving the 4 wheelers' is jacked up enough to be exactly like the fools that I disliked back in the day that that part IS exactly as it was. LOL. All in all, pretty fun and easy to see that someone could start out on this and 'get a feel' for the real thing and be more comfortable IF they were planning on driving for a living.

As if the graphics weren't sweet enough, it is surprising how realistic this crafted gem has come to be (with exception to the length of drive times for long missions, the clock is naturally compressed in this sim as opposed to spending all day behind the glass on the actual open road). You can switch between manual and automatic shifting, the turn radius of the simulated truck is comparable to the real thing, even the customization options are extensive and impressive. You can be a solo driver or a have your own fleet. Short day trips or over the road (otr) long haul. About the only improvement I'D like to see is actually livestreaming authentic satellite radio into your virtual truck from your SXM subscription. Such an advent would be nothing short of stunning. This simulator is a definitive treat!

As a truck driver with over 16.5 years experience & just being introduced to this game.....it is simply ASTOUNDING that I can actually recognize some of the places. I've been to ALL of the lower 48 & every province in Canada EXCEPT Novia Scotia & the Northern Territories.  One of my FAVORITE places to stop at was Haugen, MT. I COULDN'T BELIEVE the ATTENTION TO DETAIL I saw on the simulator.  EVERYTHING looks almost SPOT ON it was ALMOST like I was really there! The layout of the buildings,  the detail on the buildings,  right down to the big yellow sign that says "TRUCKS" in red letters & my FAVORITE was the detail on the 50'000 Silver Dollar building! As far as the ATTENTION TO DETAIL  on the trucks, trailers & other equipment....SIMPLY AMAZING!  The interiors are EXACTLY PERFECT!  EVERYTHING ABOUT THIS GAME IS IMPRESSIVE!! I CAN'T WAIT TO SEE WHAT OTHER UPDATES COME ALONG & WHAT THEY COME UP WITH NEXT!! VERY IMPRESSED!! I'D SHAKE HANDS WITH EVERYONE INVOLVED IN PUTTING TIME & EFFORT INTO THIS!! FANTASTIC JOB!!!

ATS rating: 9/10; see other [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44763882-Sim-Reviews/?appid=2014780]Sim Reviews[/url]

[quote=TLDR]Haul lumber through dusty backroads, dodge scales like a coyote in chicken coop, and squeeze every penny from those fuel-gobblin' hogs. Earn your stripes and watch your bank account swell like a busted dam. Soon you'll be rollin' in a monster rig, a palace on wheels with more pizzazz than a Vegas showgirl. Customise that beast like a tattoo parlor, make it purr like a kitten, and watch other truckers gawk as you rumble past.[/quote]

American Truck Simulator (ATS), from the masterminds at SCS Software, is more than just a driving game; it's an immersive odyssey across the majestic American highways, where you wield the reins of an 18-wheeled behemoth. From the sun-kissed shores of California to the endless plains of Kansas, ATS lets you live the trucker's dream behind the wheel of iconic American rigs like Peterbilt, Kenworth, and Mack.

Compared to its European counterpart, Euro Truck Simulator 2, ATS boasts a more laid-back vibe. It's all about savouring the scenery and the rhythmic rumble of your engine as you conquer mile after mile of asphalt. ATS specialises in epic journeys, where you haul diverse cargo across vast stretches of the American landscape. Buckle up for cross-country treks that test your endurance and reward you with breathtaking vistas.

[b]Gameplay and Mechanics[/b]

You kick off with just a basic truck, and each delivery is a step towards your big dream. It's not just about steering a truck from point A to B; it's about nurturing your very own business from the ground up. Every successful job means more cash in your pocket, paving the way for upgrades, new trucks, and eventually, a fleet under your command.

But what really sets this game apart is its devotion to realism. Driving isn't just pressing buttons; it's about feeling the road. Each truck has its own personality, its handling quirks. The weight of your cargo isn't just a number ‚Äì it's a tangible presence that affects how you drive. It's about getting the hang of shifting gears like a pro, mastering the art of air brakes, and handling every twist and turn with finesse.

The control setup is pretty flexible. Whether you're a casual gamer using a keyboard and mouse, or a true enthusiast with a steering wheel and pedal rig, the game adapts to your style. And if you're into head-tracking for that extra bit of realism, the game‚Äôs got you covered. Using an Xbox controller combined with a webcam for head-tracking? That's a neat and cheap setup that strikes a balance between casual and immersive gameplay.

And then there's the business management side of things. It's like playing two games in one. On one hand, you're the driver, and on the other, you're the boss. Taking out loans, buying trucks, hiring drivers ‚Äì it's a slow but satisfying journey to becoming a tycoon of the trucking world. The economic aspect is not just tacked on; it's a well-thought-out system that mirrors the gradual climb from a lone driver to a business magnate. It's a game that rewards patience, strategy, and a love for the open road.

[b]Graphics and Sound[/b]

American Truck Simulator really is a love letter to the open road. It's like they've taken the essence of the American landscape and packed it into your screen. As you drive through the game, it's the little things that catch your eye ‚Äì the way a city skyline looks at dusk, how a landmark is just perfectly placed. It's all about the details here, and they've nailed it.

Sure, it might not be flexing the latest, cutting-edge graphics, but honestly, it doesn't need to. It's more about how the game feels. The landscapes and cityscapes have this authentic vibe that pulls you in. Even though you might spot a rough edge here and there, or a spot that's not as polished, it's easy to overlook because the overall experience is so engaging.

And then there's the weather. It's not just eye candy. When the rain starts pouring down or the fog rolls in, you feel it. It changes how you drive, adds a layer of challenge, and cranks up the realism a notch.

Each truck has its own distinct engine growl that changes with the engine type, what you're hauling, and even the way you're driving. It's those ambient sounds ‚Äì the whoosh of the wind or the patter of rain‚Äì that really round out the experience. And if you're into mods, you can amp up these sounds even more. They've thought of everything to make you feel like you're right there, in the driver's seat, cruising down an American highway.

[b]Customisation[/b]

Customising your truck in this game isn't just a feature, it's an art form. It's like your truck is a blank canvas, and you're the artist. You can get really nitty-gritty with it, fine-tuning everything from the engine right down to the paint job. It's all about expressing yourself, showing off your unique style as you hit the road.

Picture this: you're scrolling through a rainbow of colours and designs, picking out that perfect look. You've got everything from classic solid colours to flashy metallic finishes, and some designs that are straight out of a trucker's dream. And it's not just about the exterior. Inside the cab, you can deck it out with your favourite gadgets, maybe hang a couple of cool trinkets, or set up a laptop for those long hauls.

Lighting? Oh, it's a game-changer. Throw on some LED strips or powerful spotlights on the roof, and your truck becomes this majestic beast gliding through the night. And headlights aren't just for show ‚Äì they're practical too, helping you cut through foggy mornings or heavy rain.

Under the hood, it gets even more exciting. Boost your engine for speed, better handling of heavy loads, or just to save on fuel. Tweak the transmission for different terrains, finding that sweet spot between power and efficiency. And the chassis? That's where you fine-tune your truck's agility and stability, making sure it's fit for whatever cargo you're hauling.

And we're not done yet. Wheels, tires, hubcaps, exhausts, grills, light bars... the list goes on. Whether you're going for rugged, sleek, or downright flashy, there's something for every taste. It's not just a truck; it's your personal statement on wheels.

[b]Content and Modding[/b]

The modding scene really brings this game to life, and with Steam Workshop in the mix, it's like a never-ending treasure trove of cool stuff. Imagine being able to tweak and twist your gameplay with thousands of mods ‚Äì it's like giving your game a personal touch with new maps, trucks, addons and more.

The devs are also continually rolling out DLCs that keep things fresh. Every DLC drop is like a mini celebration, bringing in new areas to explore, different types of cargo and trailers, and even snazzy paint jobs for your rig. The expansion packs are more than just extra miles to cover; they bring in little slices of the real world, like the local traffic rules, different road types, architecture, and even a certain space port in Texas. It's all about making you feel like you're really there.

What's cool is that the base map isn't left behind ‚Äì it gets its own facelifts, keeping up with the new shiny stuff. And the older DLCs? They're getting makeovers too, so they're just as awesome as the new ones. The game keeps evolving, so keep your eyes peeled for the latest updates and new areas to explore. It's all part of making your virtual trucking world richer and more immersive.

[b]Overall[/b]

ATS really hits the sweet spot for a wide range of players. It's like a chameleon in the gaming world ‚Äì it can be this chill, almost zen-like experience where you're just cruising through breathtaking landscapes, soaking in the sights of American countryside and cities. For players who just want to unwind and take a leisurely drive across scenic routes, ATS is a perfect escape.

I wish there was something in between thumbs up & thumbs down.  There's a lot to like about this game if you like relaxing sims.  ...  In theory...
  There are scenic views (not great graphics but alright) like you would expect, but it seems like so many little things pop up to just stress you out it's kind of ridiculous.  Like the re-routing.  I have no idea who programmed that but I could think of a lot of things I'd like to say about them.  If you don't constantly watch the map even when there aren't supposed to be any deviations in your course then it will likely decide to randomly re-route you.  We're not talking google maps where it will generally find a somewhat reasonable alternative route.  We're talking being re-routed around the entire state in a circle and you going far down that road before you realize.  Literally adding 3-4x the length to your journey.  Then you get frustrated, make some mistakes, take damage you can't fix (trailer damage is unfixable) so they'd have you doing 45mph in a loop around the entire state of Nevada.
  If they fixed that & a few other things it would be a great game, though.

This game started out excellent many years ago but has been continually upgraded (for free) to improve its visual, audio and game play quality.  It simply keeps getting better and better as the years go by.

Over all I believe I have enough hours in this game to say, they have done an absolutely amazing job. I just got the game when it was on sale for Christmas and have played it back to back in single player and multi-player. 

Single player is great, the game is relaxing and aesthetically pleasing I did like the in game music but inevitably switched to Spotify to listen to my music. I started out playing with Mouse and Keyboard (hated it). I Have a PS5 so I decided to use my PS5 controller, I myself tweaked the settings just slightly on sensitivity but overall out of the gate the settings were near perfect. After a little playing around on single player I added some mods to see what has come around. I myself like the most realistic settings possible and the Mods didn't disappoint. Not only a real feel cabin suspension wise but an overhaul to the graphics and the economy really change the game. At this point I decided to make a "Hard" Profile and an online "no mods" Profile. If you want to use Mods I suggest making 2 profiles

Online is great of course you have kids and people who just want to go as fast as possible into you and the wall but overall after hosting my own session I have been able to do thousands of miles in Convoys with other players. My only suggestions for anyone hosting, manage your server well or the high Latency people will inevitably cause Lag and you to hit a truck that was 300ft in front them under you. Overall the online stability I think needs a little more improvement as I found Myself keeping Latency for my server under 60 for the best results with a max of 7 people. Overall for Online its great and allot of middle aged crowd is nice.

DLC's/Game Layout. I do have a complaint, although it may be more realistic that certain cargo ships for more money per mile than others some of the "cool" or crazy cargo is low paying for transportation and kinda diverts your attention to what pays best for the first 100 or so hours of game play. My suggestion would be a little bit of a change once in a while in cargo types and looks having different Per mile gains to keep the interest in taking different types of loads and not just what pays best.

My Absolute biggest wish is for more trucks to be added or more customization for my personal preference Freightliner.
 
Final Decision: I Love this game online and off, with Mods and without and highly suggest it for anyone who enjoys a good Tractor Trailer, or a relaxing friendly environment in multiplayer.

I originally wrote a bad review for this game but I'm revising it due to a far more superior experience after revisiting it. The Game feels pretty much the same as Eurotruck simulator for the most part. My one qualm with this game that I still have from my initial run is that some of the parking spaces are absolutely absurd. This was something I hated and made a point of in my first review and this has not be fixed. there are some parking spots in places that are so awful it's near impossible to park and for that i'm docking this 2 points. That being said the rest of the game plays well and it's equally as good as Eurotruck sim. One other small thing that I personally dislike is the very boxy hoods on the Freightliner trucks. They stick out too far and obstruct too much of the view. However that's just the style of the truck that I'm hating on. I will save that hate for my review of Freightliner trucks. JK.

American Truck Simulator 5/19/23 This is a truck simulator, not a trucking simulator, there's a difference. Beyond the graphics the simulation ends. It is just another sh**y video game. Full of tricks, deceptions, lies and illusion. This was the easy thing to do,. They didn't put much effort into research to make the game a realistic trucking experience, with real word trucking headaches.
But it is a fun game, as you can see, I have been playing it for many hours. This is my first review of it. I curse it, I love it, I hate it, I love it.

7/25/23 I haven't played this game much lately. I have all the garages, trucks and drivers. All the states. I don't like OTR driving that much, but I did it enough to make millions and millions of dollars.
So what now? I have nothing to spend my money on. I took a vacation, if you will, and let my drivers make me rich, while I drove around and found the rest of the recruitment agencies.

I hated night time driving, they made it really hard at first, but it seemed to get easier as time went on. Don't know why.

12/15/23 I now have Kansas and Oklahoma, I'll buy the garages, I like to stop and fuel and sleep in my garages, but not the trucks. I have lots of male drivers and all the female drivers. Not going to buy more trucks till they get more female drivers. I am a guy, I'm just partial to women. I have discovered all the recruitment agencies, no women available.
I have over 500 million $, nothing to spend it on.

1/6/24 I have all this money. It would be nice if I could buy the "Truck Works" garages. Maybe get a truck dealership franchise, that would be cool. Buy or build a string of truck stops.

American Truck Simulator for Steam has become my go-to gaming indulgence, thanks to its unparalleled realism and attention to detail. The game's meticulous recreation of American landscapes and cities, coupled with authentic truck-driving mechanics, creates an immersive experience that feels remarkably true to life. Whether cruising through the vast expanses of Nevada or navigating the intricate streets of Los Angeles, the graphics and design evoke a genuine sense of traversing the American highways. The freedom to explore a vast open world, customize trucks, and the continuous support from the development team through updates and expansions contribute to the game's enduring appeal. American Truck Simulator isn't just a game; it's a captivating journey that captures the essence of the open road in a way that keeps me hooked for countless hours of virtual trucking adventures.

Excellent driving sim! Having played almost all the SCS classics, this is by far the most well done and enjoyable of them all. The routes are obviously very condensed but hit key points within the respective states. Lots of trucks,trailers, and different load outs! There are several frustrating parts of the game that hopefully SCS can fix. The AI traffic literally almost stops when merging on or off the highway or making turns. When the highways reduce from two lanes to one the traffic comes to a screeching halt. When there is highway construction, or highway incidents the traffic stops. The AI traffic needs work and needs to be smoother. The next complaint is the traffic lights, a gamer literally spends more time at empty stop light intersections than one does going down the road. Maybe developing a sensing light that senses the Player truck at an empty light and changing would be great rather than the same time on every single light.

American Truck Simulator (ATS) is a captivating simulation game that puts players behind the wheel of powerful trucks, allowing them to traverse the diverse landscapes of the United States. Released by SCS Software, ATS offers a realistic and immersive trucking experience. Here's a breakdown of the game's strengths and weaknesses:

The Good:

1. Realistic Driving Experience:
   ATS excels in delivering a lifelike driving experience. The attention to detail in truck mechanics, road layouts, and traffic behavior contributes to an immersive simulation that feels authentic.

2. Stunning Visuals:
   The game boasts impressive graphics, showcasing the beauty of America's landscapes. From the sunsets over the Nevada desert to the rain-soaked roads in Washington, ATS captures the essence of each region with stunning visuals.

3. Expansive Map:
   The game features a vast map, with additional DLCs expanding the virtual representation of the United States. This extensive road network provides players with countless hours of exploration and varied routes for transporting goods.

4. Realistic Economy System:
   ATS incorporates a detailed economic system where players manage their own trucking business. From purchasing and upgrading trucks to hiring drivers, the game offers a comprehensive business simulation that adds depth to the overall experience.

5. Modding Community:
   The active modding community enhances the game by introducing new trucks, trailers, and map expansions. This not only extends the lifespan of ATS but also provides players with an array of customization options.

The Bad:

1. Limited Variety in Missions:
   Despite the realism in driving, the missions can become repetitive over time. The tasks mainly revolve around delivering goods from one point to another, lacking the variety seen in other simulation games.

2. AI Traffic Behavior:
   The behavior of AI-controlled vehicles can be erratic at times. Unpredictable movements and occasional traffic jams can break the immersion and result in frustrating situations for players.

3. Resource Intensive:
   ATS demands a relatively powerful PC to run smoothly, and players with lower-end systems may face performance issues. Optimization could be improved to cater to a wider audience.

4. Limited Multiplayer Features:
   While ATS introduced a multiplayer mode, its features are somewhat limited compared to its single-player counterpart. More robust multiplayer options could enhance the social aspect of trucking across America.

Conclusion:

American Truck Simulator is a commendable simulation game that offers a genuine trucking experience with its realistic driving mechanics, stunning visuals, and expansive map. Despite some areas for improvement, such as mission variety and AI behavior, ATS provides an enjoyable journey for players who appreciate the beauty of the open road and the challenges of the trucking industry. With a dedicated modding community and ongoing support from the developers, American Truck Simulator continues to evolve, promising an even more engaging experience in the future.

Alright, buckle up, you magnificent road warriors, 'cause American Truck Simulator is here to turn your mundane commute into a trucking extravaganza that's more addictive than grandma's secret cookie stash. Strap in tight, 'cause we're about to roll through the highways of hilarity!

First things first, this game is like therapy for your inner trucker, without the overpriced couch. The attention to detail is so spot-on that I half expected a virtual CB radio to start crackling with trucker lingo and a GPS to nag me about missing the exit. I've never had so much joy navigating a digital vehicle through the virtual streets of America ‚Äì and I've played Mario Kart on a banana peel.

The sheer joy of cruising down endless roads, watching the sunrise over the Rockies, and trying not to knock over every mailbox in sight is enough to make even the most hardcore gamers reconsider their life choices. The realism is mind-blowing, and I never thought I'd say this, but maneuvering an 18-wheeler through tight spaces is oddly satisfying ‚Äì like threading a needle with a sledgehammer. American Truck Simulator has turned me into a virtual trucking legend, and I haven't even scratched the surface of the DLCs yet. Just remember, folks, this game is more addictive than caffeine and way better for your heart than a triple-shot espresso. Get ready to roll, laugh, and maybe curse a bit when you realize you've taken the wrong exit for the umpteenth time ‚Äì but hey, that's just part of the chaotic charm. Happy truckin'! üööüí®

I will always have my criticisms with this game and also ETS2 but that's just because of how much I love these games. I don't think there is a single game out there that not only has a map as big as this but also the driving experience as well. There's simply nothing better than driving around in your semi-truck hauling goods while listening to music or a podcast. The modding community definitely enhances the experience of this game by a ton with plenty of map mods, truck mods, trailer mods, etc (albeit some of the best ones are payware but that's up to you if you want to spend money on payware mods)

I‚Äôve been a gamer for well over 30 years, rarely has a game captivated my attention, satisfaction and time like ATS has. 

Don‚Äôt expect a 1:1 US highway rendition, it is a cleverly designed and compressed map of virtual major highways, cities and notable landmarks in an ever expanding DLC statewide expansion. On the surface it sounds incredibly boring, sitting in a drivers cab travelling from Point A to Point B, literally for hours delivering cargo for a your virtual trucking company. 

But from my perspective, the satisfaction is with the exploration of a uniquely created vast map. Some of the longer Point A to Point B routes can easily take an hour of your time.

Throw in some of the built in Internet radio streams and the time just melts away. The day and night cycles create some absolutely captivating dusk and dawn scenes. The environmental and skybox color palette is spot on, whether it‚Äôs the lonely deserts of the south west or the busy north western pacific region. The built in photo studio helps capture any mesmerizing moments you encounter whilst on your virtual cargo delivery journeys.

Let‚Äôs talk about the trade-offs. The cities are cleverly designed to give the impression they are bigger than they actually are. It‚Äôs deliberate, like a movie set with landmark and building props. Likewise with some of the blocked roads, they are deliberately created to create the impression of a larger world. 

I‚Äôve traveled many of the highways and visited the places outlined in ATS, the developers have made a tremendous effort to capture the atmosphere, culture and industries of the different locations with their models and assets. 

Given the sheer scale of the map, one would expect some copy and paste. Honestly though, subconsciously whilst driving you rarely see it, almost everything appears unique in the ATS world. I can‚Äôt judge the accuracy of the trucks, since I don‚Äôt have daily exposure to them. However, the artistic assets for road markings, signage, locations, lighting gantries, barriers and vehicles are spot on for each state. I‚Äôve dabbled in gaming asset development, I can tell a tremendous amount of hard work has gone into getting it feeling right and working right. Example, alleviating distant scenery pop-up etc. by using other closer visual assets to obscure distant transition or the curvature of the road obscuring localized scenery pop-up.   
SCS Software has created a very impressive piece of PC gaming software that highlights unique artistic creativity, landmark/route trade-offs and a jigsaw mentality in trying to seamlessly bring it all together as you traverse each of the currently available US states with their DLC. 

Give it a try, stick with it, you won‚Äôt be disappointed.

Prefer it to ETS2 personally, can't compete with a game that has you traverse the great and varied expanse of the United States. They are practically the same game though, the only real difference is the landscape and available trucks. Gameplay loop between the two is identical. 

Anyway, it is a game about driving trucks, and managing your trucking company. If it were only one of those things then it wouldn't be as fun.
I get satisfaction from managing a trucking business, this passively makes money in the background. You hire drivers and buy trucks which go around the country making you money.
I then get even more satisifaction from actually just driving the truck around. It is very relaxing, and really exactly what you would expect. This is the main gameplay loop. You take a transport job in a town that will send you to another town. As you progress, the types of goods you transport change, the distance increases, and you make more money. Starting out you just move smalls trailers short distances, which will probably only take you a few minutes in real life. Eventually you will be hauling massive heavy trailers very long distances which can take well up to an hour or more in real time.  

If you don't enjoy taking road trips, or don't get any enjoyment from being on a highway, then you won't like this game. It is an expensive game too, with the mass amounts of DLC now available.

Having logged a jaw-dropping 60+ hours behind the wheel in the virtual world of American Truck Simulator, I feel like an honorary member of the long-haul fraternity. This game isn't just a simulator; it's a rollercoaster ride in a 40-ton steel behemoth. You see, it's not every day you get to commandeer those mammoth trucks you play leapfrog with on the highway (a friendly wave here, a less-than-friendly honk there - trucker life, am I right?).

Now, I've had my stint with European Truck Simulator, and it was a hoot, but American Truck Simulator hits closer to home. It's like a love letter to those iconic Big Rigs. Sadly, my little hometown didn't make the cut into the game. I guess we're just a blip on the map - too small for even the virtual world!

And oh, the truck weighing stations! As a regular Joe in a sedan, I've always wondered what mystical rituals transpire in those roadside temples. Spoiler alert: they just weigh trucks. Who knew?

But let's talk DLCs. If DLCs were a train, this one would stretch all the way to the Australian outback. They've got a DLC for every state. I mean, c'mon, at this rate, I'd need to grow extra fingers on my feet to count them all. It's like they're saying, "Why bundle states when we can sell them one by one?" Sure, it's cool to virtually visit your hometown or your favorite vacay spot, but my wallet's giving me the stink eye.

Don't get me wrong, you don't need all the DLCs to enjoy the game. But if you're a collector, brace yourself. Your piggy bank might start giving you the silent treatment.

In summary, American Truck Simulator is a delightful escapade into the world of trucking. It's where rubber meets the road, and your living room turns into the cab of a Peterbilt or Kenworth. Just be ready to navigate the labyrinth of DLCs - or not. Your call, trucker!
"It's a hard job change gear change gear change gear check your mirrors murder a prostitute change gear change gear murder check your... that's a lot of effort in a day." -Jezza

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Have you ever wondered what it would be like to just buy a semi truck and drive freight all over the great landscapes of the United States? Now you can, with this game. You start out just doing quick one off jobs and try to earn enough cash to get a loan and get your first rig. And then you keep running jobs on the market to upgrade that truck, or trade it in and get an even better one. Then you buy more garages so you can have even more trucks, and hire drivers to earn your trucking company even more cash. You can get sucked in for hours on hours on hours doing all of this.

The base game came with California and Nevada? And Arizona was free. The other states are DLC but all are so well done. The older states they have released will usually go on sale from 50-75% off when they run sales, and if you just get them to do the acheivement to just visit each city in every state, youll easily get your money's worth. 

This is a great game developer, so I would highly suggest this game. They have been constantly working on this and Euro Truck 2 for over a decade.

Came back to this game in 2023 to find voice-guided navigation added. A game changer. There's now less need to look at map so we can enjoy scenery and watch the road.   Lighting and skies also improved and look amazing. 

Now looks even better on ultrawide display with TrackIR and farming sim wheel and pedals.

[b]TrackIR: [/b]Once you dial in smoothness and speed in TrackIR, and adjust driver position in ATS with F4, the experience is very good. 

[b]My track IR settings:[/b]
* Speed: 3.5
* Smooth: 27
* Motion Adjustment Template: OneOne

[b]Farming sim wheel and pedals[/b]
These are not high quality, but do the job well. Because we can reduce the sensitivity of the brakes in the ATS settings, it's possible to get "squishy" brakes even out of these cheap pedals. Same with gas pedal. I set it so the brakes feel slightly sluggish and the gas nice and loose to avoid twitchy acceleration. The pedals feel more realistic after making these adjustments. 

[h3]Wishlist[/h3] 

* Different machinery to operate on-site after delivery.  Cranes, forklifts, control panels, something not difficult but fun. 
* Increased scale would be nice, maybe even 1:1 similar to MS flight sim. 
* A fully open world instead of those barriers, so perhaps procedural generated to increase areas to travel.  I prefer more realistic, bigger distances and time scales. Real time, with option to speed up and skip ahead.

Let's start with the tutorial directions at the end of the tutorial.  Understand I've never played a trucking game.

"At the terminal(ok I made it there and understand that), once you have selected your desired parking spot(how do I do that?) you may choose an easier alternate spot(ok but like how do I do that turtorial?)  If you get into any trouble,(so far the only trouble I've had is the tutorial itself) you may choose to complete the delivery automatically.(Great suggestion.  You know what'd be better? IF YOU TOLD ME HOW TO DO THAT INSTEAD.)

A rectangular area will be highlighted(I'm assuming that is the bouncing trailer symbol that doesn't do anything when you park your trailer in it) and marked in the route advisor(random golf flag far off from where it actually wants you to go) as the place to park the trailer.(doesn't do anything unless it is your truck cab.  Not the trailer)  When the trailer is properly positioned,(wtf does that even mean?) a message will appear asking you to detach it.(Had the trailer fully covering the trailer icon.  Did absolutely nothing until I had the truck cab parked on the trailer icon.)"


I bought this game due to the great reviews and watching some limited amount of streamed content on Steam here.  Having played through the tutorial which was worthless and a few jobs I couldn't recommend this game.  There are really good parts marred by horrendously done nuances with no purpose other than to infuriate the player.  The GPS is worse than when GPS was first introduced on phones.  I can never tell where it or when it wants me to turn.  I've always wondered how people drive off a cliff following GPS but if it was the GPS from American Truck Simulator it now makes complete sense.

The visuals are really good.  Great work there.  

Sound fits the theme and is good for what it does.

Driving is laughably bad.  You know those racing games where you can do 200 miles per hour and stay perfectly in the lines?  This system is so poorly designed doing 60 on the freeway and I'm a diagonal box covering my lane on any minor curve.  Really?  You can't even make a driving system that can manage the lines at 60 miles per hour?

Getting the jobs felt like a good system.  Then you have to use the GPS to get to the locations and that is a nightmare.

It seems like there is a bunch of good content up ahead but I don't know if I can stomach how bad accessing it is because of these other really bad systems.  Like white grids on gray asphalt to drop the trailer during a bright day.  Is that really easy to see?  That's the best you could come up with?  Really?

Lastly, I was also excited to play with family.  Bought 3 copies.  This may or may not be ATS fault.  It could be Steam. I am not sure.  We have played plenty of other games together but the entire time I was connecting and disconnecting from the convoy.  We never got through a proper game together.  I had to play solo.  We all play in the same house and the other 2 were just fine playing with each other.  So, again, this last part I have no idea why the convoy experience was bad in my singular case.  Take that for what it is.

I love this game! This game is amazing for a variety of reasons. Let me start with the first one. Firstly, this game is $19.99 dollars, which is an unbelievably reasonable price for a game where you get to experience the thrill of driving a truck. Secondly, the name "American Truck Simulator" is super original and an overall brilliant take on a Steam name game. Thirdly, the graphics are amazing and completely worth the price. Secondly, the sensitivity is perfect, and the settings are extremely easy to maneuver, which is great. Next, there's just enough action to keep you engaged without being overwhelming. Thirdly, the options of customization allow you to choose between two genders, male and female, providing a simple and clear experience. This game is inclusive and respectful of diverse identities. Inclusion has led to a more harmonious gaming community, and it is the root of all joy. Plus, this game has a stellar reputation for being very affordable, which I already mentioned. And let me start on the driving mechanics. Firstly, you don't need to get out of your car, which is a brilliant upside. Oh, and did I mention that the characters are perfectly diverse, allowing you to express yourself freely? Plus, why would you play this game in real life when you can enjoy simulated adventures without any real-life risks? This game is realistic and exciting, as you experience the thrill of driving in a vehicle. Whenever you turn your steering wheel, it responds smoothly, providing a realistic and satisfying driving experience. And when you get stuck, you can call a tow truck to assist you, making the game more realistic and immersive. Did I mention that it takes just the right amount of time to get to your destination for fake game money? It makes perfect sense why you would enjoy driving in this engaging game for hours rather than engaging in the stresses of real life. Also, when you park, it takes just the right amount of time to actually park the vehicle, providing a realistic and challenging experience. You just make it realistic to provide a greater level of immersion for players, which means the owners of this game are attentive to player experience and value. The time it takes is perfect, everything is amazing, and the progress you make is absolutely satisfying. It takes just the right amount of time to refill gas, and it takes a reasonable amount of money to pay for the damage that you have made, so when you finally finish enjoying 90 minutes of your life and get to the end of the task that you have finished, you feel accomplished and successful. This is society nowadays, creating games for enjoyment and entertainment, giving the player a rewarding experience in return. So the money you spent on this game basically makes you happy and provides a guarantee of satisfaction for your money. I love this game so much, as it offers an immersive experience and is overall a fantastic game to spend your money on. I completely understand why this game is still on the Steam market.
