This game is condemned to become unviable. Playing it is becoming a nightmare. The frame freezing issue, the stuttering, is getting worse with each new version, each new DLC and each new feature. 
The overall art and presentation of the game world (roads, landscapes, cities, buildings, monuments, businesses, etc.) are phenomenal, rich in details, and wonderfully beautiful. The trucks are amazing, almost perfect. 
But technical problems multiply, demonstrating the inability of SCS programmers to promote the evolution of the game's graphics engine and system basic functions, such as loading, reloading and saving, to keep up with hardware evolution. 
Why mandate new system requirements if they don't make proper use of them? High-spec hardware like PCIe 5.0 M.2 NVMe SSDs, high-end processors like Ryzen 7 7800X3D, graphics cards like RTX 4090 and lots of available super-fast RAM, make no difference since the game core is over 10 years old and unable to handle them and all the new features introduced in recent years. 
The game continues to stutter no matter how much you lower its configuration resources trying to alleviate the problem. 
I think SCS should partner with some specialized programming consultancy company to find a solution, as it has proven incapable of doing, by itself, the hard technical work required to keep the game relevant in today's highly competitive market. 
As it stands now, I regret all the money I spent on this game and will no longer put a dime on it, unless a drastic positive attitude change happens.
If they want to squeeze more money out of us gamers to pay for the new SCS office building, for example, they will have to perform much better and keep us happy with state-of-the-art programming techniques. The Labor of Love award no longer justifies this delay.

A good game if it is what you want. It is not what I was looking for. In this game you try to run a prescribed route in the best time/cost, tracked against other players.  Its a online game...So essentially a rat running a maze compared to  other rats. I have played other simulators where its more about exploring routes...take the scenic route and come out ahead or behind.. take the express route ... live with the consequences ... Something with a lot variation along the route so there is a lot of replay ability. I did not have a  good starting experience. I got hung up on a small wall checking out the maneuverability of the truck with the computer inputs. Something you would do with driving any new vehicle. When I looked around the  truck, no does not look like I am touching the wall ...but I guess I am....  So I tried to restart the run ..nope you can't restart a run, but you can't finish the run...I had to create a new character because your record is your record. Just bad design. So it is not a game for me. I wanted a stand alone game that I could  explore.

I've played a lot of Euro Truck Sim 2 and picked this up on sale awhile back because Merica! It's a fun simulator you that you can play with a keyboard, Xbox controller(Recommended), or go full sim fashion with a wheel, H-shifter and pedals. At the time of this review the base game is $4.99 and some bundles are over 50% off which will give you 2 more US States to spread your trucking empire into. American Truck Simulator is a truly wonderful game that is easy to recommend to fellow gamers. The driving is both relaxing and enjoyable. Cruising the open road in a big rig and listening to your favorite tunes while taking in all the magnificent views never gets old.

There are multiple truck models to choose from including plenty of truck and trailer customization options with paint jobs and accessories galore. The DLC's are not necessary to enjoy the game, but I still recommend them. The level of detail in different terrains, flora, and landmarks from state to state is rather impressive.

The developers, SCS Software, are among the best in the business. Their dedication to this project and the love they pour into each update shines through with flying colors. They update the community on a regular basis with details about what is going on with future game development. I honestly can't say enough good things about SCS Software.

I've not played ATS with a keyboard and mouse, but I can say that it plays well with a controller and even better with a wheel and pedals. So, again, this is an easy thumbs up for me and if you do decide to buy ATS, I hope you enjoy your time on the open road as much as I have.

[b][u]Edit: November 22, 2023[/u][/b]

Two years since writing this review and SCS Software is still adding content and polish to this title. Much respect for that level of dedication and post-release development.

I'm nominating American Truck Simulator for Steam's Labor of Love Award 2023. Keep up the good work, SCS. You guys rock!

A Journey Across the Heartland - American Truck Simulator's Triumph

American Truck Simulator is a game that transcends the boundaries of conventional gaming experiences, offering players a unique and immersive journey into the heartland of the United States. As an ardent fan of simulation games, I found myself captivated by the unparalleled realism and attention to detail that make American Truck Simulator a true gem in the genre.

One of the standout features of the game is its meticulously crafted world, faithfully recreating the diverse landscapes of America. From the majestic mountains of Colorado to the sun-soaked highways of California, every inch of the virtual terrain is a testament to the developers' commitment to authenticity. The attention to detail is so meticulous that driving through the various states feels like embarking on a genuine cross-country road trip.

The realism extends beyond the visuals, with an impressive array of licensed trucks that handle with precision and nuance. Each truck feels unique, capturing the essence of their real-world counterparts. The level of customization available, from tweaking engine performance to fine-tuning the aesthetics of your rig, adds a layer of personalization that enhances the overall gaming experience.

American Truck Simulator's commitment to realism also extends to its dynamic weather system and day-night cycle. Navigating through a snowstorm in the northern states or witnessing a breathtaking sunset while cruising through the desert creates an immersive atmosphere that draws players deeper into the game world.

The game's economy system is another aspect that sets it apart. Managing a virtual trucking business requires strategic thinking and careful planning. Balancing fuel costs, maintenance expenses, and delivery deadlines adds a layer of complexity that elevates American Truck Simulator beyond a mere driving simulation.

Beyond the solo experience, the multiplayer mode adds a social dimension to the game, allowing players to convoy with friends or other virtual truckers. The cooperative aspect of delivering cargo together creates a sense of camaraderie, turning the virtual highways into a bustling community of trucking enthusiasts.

Furthermore, the developers have shown a remarkable commitment to ongoing improvement and expansion. Regular updates and the introduction of new states ensure that the game remains fresh, keeping players engaged with a continuous stream of content.

In conclusion, American Truck Simulator is a triumph in the simulation genre. Its unparalleled realism, attention to detail, and commitment to an evolving gaming experience make it a standout title. Whether you're a trucking aficionado or a gamer looking for a unique and immersive journey, American Truck Simulator delivers an unforgettable and enjoyable ride across the vast landscapes of the United States.

American Truck Simulator is not just a game; it's an emotional odyssey that captivates players with its charm, warmth, and delightful road trips. From the moment I embarked on this truck-filled adventure, I found myself immersed in a world that seamlessly blends whimsy with profound emotions.

The visuals are a feast for the eyes, featuring a vibrant and beautifully crafted environment that mirrors a truck's inherent uplifting aura. The driving, reminiscent of a real life truck drive, creates an enchanting atmosphere that pulls you into its embrace.

What truly sets American Truck Simulator apart is its ability to evoke genuine emotions. The trucks are well-developed, each with their unique quirks and personalities, making it easy to connect with them on a personal level. Each state you drive through is breathtakingly heartfelt, contributing to a experience that effortlessly tugs at the heartstrings.

The gameplay is both engaging and accessible, striking a perfect balance between challenge and enjoyment. Parking and other tasks are seamlessly integrated into every haul, ensuring that each moment spent playing contributes to your desired overall narrative arc. The game encourages exploration, allowing players to uncover hidden gems and intricacies that add depth to the overall experience.

The soundtrack is a standout feature, perfectly complementing the emotional highs and lows of the journey. From uplifting melodies during moments of joy to gentle tunes that accompany reflective scenes, the music enhances the emotional impact of the adventure.

American Truck Simulator is more than just a game; it's a celebration of love, friendship, and the intricacies of human connections. It's a rare gem that manages to strike a balance between perfect gameplay mechanics and heartfelt, lifelong desire to drive a truck, leaving players with a warm glow that lingers long after the long haul is complete. If you're in search of a game that goes beyond entertainment and leaves a lasting impression, American Truck Simulator is a must-play experience that reminds us all that, indeed, trucks.

Ok, this one is tough for me.
I really do love just sitting down, turning on the radio, and having a 5 hour session. There is truly nothing like this game, it is just so peaceful. But I can't recommend this to everyone. I feel like some people will get bored of this very easily, and it wouldn't be worth the money they spent. On the other hand, this game is so relaxing, and it is so much fun to go trucking with your friends! The DLC's are my one complaint. You have to pay almost $100 (growing cost wise every day) to get the USA. Also, if you buy some states, but you don't own the surrounding ones, it is impossible to drive there. You have to fast-travel.
Also the other truck drivers don't honk back at you when you beep them :(
Overall, I would recommend this to people who enjoy long, relaxing drives, but I don't recommend this to everyone.
-Ari

This is an awesome game, the developers are constantly updating it with great stuff.  It has come a long way since launch and you can tell that the developers care about the game.  I don't play it often, but it's nice to come back to and enjoy a relaxing game and listen to music while hauling a trailer across America.  The truck models are great, the sounds are great, overall just a bargain of a game for the price they are asking.

Only two gripes, it needs a new updated game engine, and the highway on ramps are way to short. The game constantly bounces around FPS in larger cities, and I'm running a 6950XT with a 5900x at 1440p Ultra, so I'd appreciate more optimization.

The vast roads of the American West give this game a beautiful setting. However, usually only interstates and large highways are accessible, and cities feel very small. Each region does feel unique. From Arizona's deserts to Nocal's and Oregon's forests, there is variety in the environment. Players are able to be a contractor that drives company trucks, or the owner of a trucking company that manages employees. The DLC-based content distribution is rather inconvenient for players, even if it is understandable. Also, some graphics can get blurry or pixelated. To summarize, a fun drive through Western America with iffy visuals. 7/10.

What can I say about SCS truck simulator in 2022? Everybody knows it.

Everybody knows it is as big as a world, it's made with fantastic attention to detail and with the latest lighting engine it looks better than anything demanding barely half of your PC's hardware power even if you forget to upgrade it for the last 10 years. It has a lot of trucks, trailers and loads for them so you will never be bored.

What else?

Everybody knows it has bugged speed limit that is prone to jump up and down without any proper signage causing police to charge you while you are not guilty. You will also be charged for every crash the AI car makes and who cares it's not your fault as you are probably guilty for driving in this game at the first place. 

The local AI is a legend in itself still doing strange things despite being 10 years in development and keeping the well-earned title 'Artificial Idiot'. It knows nothing about traffic rules, it yields when it should go and attacks you when it should stand still. It drives on red and stays on green, it can completely block the traffic on a 6-lane highway just to let a single car to pull out of a gas station. It is written by people who don't drive and the reason why almost nobody complains is the majority of players doesn't have a real life driving experience too.

Trucks galore is an illusion as at least half of them are unusable because of awful sound. I'm not talking aestetics, the engine noise contains very loud and unpleasant low frequency leftovers just physically unbearable to listen. How could anyone be so unprofessional? What went wrong? Deaf sound engineer? Maybe. Cheap headphones? Who knows. It is made as it was made by some chap within the small SCS team and nobody will return to revise it. 

SCS is a group of amateurs happened to be in their own niche making their niche product as good as they can. The game has more problems than many other titles and would probably fail if only there was at least one more contender... But there are none.

So.

Verdict: American Truck Simulator is the best truck simulator at the moment. Number one out of... one.

P.S. There're no truck enthusiasts in SCS so if you are this type of person be prepared for the worse: incorrect badging, fictional options, missing parts and of course made-up chassis with unrealistic wheelbases. Trucks are just toys here.

American Truck Simulator is an awesome game that lets you experience the thrill of being a trucker. The best part is how realistic it feels. You'll be cruising down the highways, delivering goods, and feeling like a true road warrior.

One of the things I love about the game is the stunning scenery. The landscapes are beautifully designed, whether you're driving through busy cities or peaceful countryside. It's like taking a virtual road trip across the American states!

Another cool thing is the variety of trucks you can choose from. You've got different makes and models, each with its own unique features and handling. And if you're into customising, you'll have a blast personalising your trucks with cool paint jobs and accessories.

Now, let's talk about a few things to consider. Some players find the game play a bit repetitive since it mainly involves driving from one point to another. And while the AI of other vehicles on the road is decent, it could be more challenging to keep things exciting.

Lastly, some players have reported performance issues like frame rate drops or long loading times. It's something to keep in mind, but it doesn't take away from the overall fun.

Overall, American Truck Simulator is a fantastic game for trucking enthusiasts. It's immersive, visually stunning, and offers a great selection of trucks to choose from. Just be aware of the repetitive game play, but hey, if you're up for the open road adventure, give it a shot!

Can this game help if you if you're going to go get your CDL and do the real thing?
Yes. I did it. So many times I'm out there on the road and recognize scenarios this game showed me. This game also gave me a minds eye to see my turns in a 3rd person view. This game has real life value in terms of simulated training. With that said. I'll never play it again because it's too much like my job and I want to enjoy my break.

Is it worth it?
 On sale - YES
Full Price - Maybe.  It depends on if you want the DLC or not.  At the time of this review, I paid around $54.00 USD for the game along with every single DLC off of steam.  This is the on-sale price currently. 

The music is 5/10 with the ability to add your own tracks, so, it's not much of an issue.  [You can even add your favorite real life radio stations too!]

Graphics is about a 8/10 -- I had some issues at first with the gauges being blurry as all hell, but switching to Dx11 & installing a graphical mod fixed this issue. 

Gameplay is 10/10 at least for me.  It's super relaxing and fun to drive your own truck from state to state.  I just wish we could use "Real Life Timers" to match where we are in the world to make it feel more realistic.

Optional notes:  I wish we could have a companion on the side-seat.  Thus far, I haven't figured out a way besides mods.  I wanna get a doggo to join me!


Overall: 7/10 - While I had some issues in the beginning, they were easily fixed with some technical knowledge and a whole-hell of a lot of google searching.  This game is mod-compatible as well as steam workshop compatible AND [while the option is in beta... Remember, it's in BETA] VR compatible.   If you love simulator games like myself and always wanted to try truck driving, get it!  Points docked for DLC practices, sure it'll be a 20 dollar buy in, but if you want the actual game it'll be over 200 USD

This game does not disappoint. It has amazing scenery, the trucks are awesome, and there's a really great third party development community that keeps putting out new content, along with what SCS does. I've been playing it now for a few years, and how SCS just seems to always keep updating the game with new features and content (some free, some paid), I think other game developers should take a page out of their book. It's the game that just keeps on giving. 

If I had to pick things that I would say still need improvement, it would be the default truck sounds. They just don't do it for me. Thankfully there are some great sound mods out there that fill that void, I just wish it was default. And of course, AI traffic, while it's gotten better, could still use some tweaks. 

The only other thing I'd say is I wish the trucks weren't so clean shiny all the time. This is a small gripe I know. But in real life, trucks aren't always clean and shiny. I wish there was a little more wear and tear. But that doesn't stop the game from being enjoyable. And finally, a wish-list item would be more diverse weather with seasons. Snow in the northern parts of the map during winter and such. That would really complete the game to me. 

Overall though, this game is great. Would highly recommend.

I play both this and ETS2 on a regular basis. Why?

ATS is installed on my laptop, which I only use at work. I play that because:

- I grew up watching Hollywood movies so North America is my favorite setting.

- Sometimes I get so much downtime that I don't have any lectures at all and my coworkers find me at my desk and love to yap about their day for hours on end. ATS keeps me company enough that I don't have to devote a lot of processing power to play it like I would, say Call of Duty or Battlefield, and I still get to just enjoy watching the scenery when I'm tired of their bullshit.

ETS2 is installed at my PC at home. I play that because:

- I grew up watching Hollywood movies so I know virtually nothing about Europe and it's cool to discover it.

- My family has this ritual that they love to do a conference call after work and talk my ear off about something or the other for hours on end. ETS2 keeps me company enough that I don't have to devote a lot of processing power to play it like I would, say Call of Duty or Battlefield, and I still get to just enjoy watching the scenery when I'm tired of hearing whatever they're mouthing off about which is usually something I'm not even interested in.

BUT! While both games are based off the exact same engines, there are some differences that I personally have noticed and that's mainly that ETS2's economy is more difficult than ATS':

- Garages cost more in ETS2 than in ATS

- Trucks cost more in ETS2 than in ATS

- Payouts are shittier with all DLCs in ETS2 than in ATS without any DLCs (with the all skills maxed out in both games)

- Vehicle insurances are a thing in ATS and for a small one time fee, you're covered for all damage for life whereas in ETS2, you break the bank everytime some dumbass scratches your truck

- Employees are more likely to turn up empty handed in ETS2 than in ATS

- Employees have negligible to negative income in ETS2 than in ATS
Couldn't tell you what it's like to play the game without mods. But I absolutely love rolling the jakes in my big funni long trok through Kansas City at 2am. 10/10

American Truck Simulator delivers an engaging and unique trucking experience, skillfully blending serene landscapes, precise mechanics, and the challenges of the profession. However, the game falls short in fully embracing the desires of enthusiasts for extended cross-country hauls. The potential for vast, multi-state journeys is present but not fully realized, leaving a notable void in an otherwise commendable gaming experience.

I absolutely love American Truck Simulator! As a fan of simulation games, this one has quickly become one of my favorites. The attention to detail in this game is incredible and it truly makes you feel like you are a real truck driver on the open road.

The graphics in American Truck Simulator are stunning. The landscapes and cities are beautifully rendered and really give you a sense of the vastness and diversity of the American highways. Driving through different states and seeing different landscapes is always a new and exciting experience.

The gameplay is also very realistic. From following traffic laws to maneuvering your truck through tight spaces, every aspect of driving a truck is accurately represented in the game. I also appreciate the variety of realistic truck brands and customization options available.

One of my favorite features of this game is the ability to listen to your own music while driving. This really adds to the immersive experience and makes long drives more enjoyable. I also love the radio stations in the game that play real songs and have entertaining DJs.

The map in the game is constantly expanding, with new states and routes being added through updates. This keeps the game fresh and exciting, with endless possibilities for exploring and delivering cargo.

My only minor complaint is that the game can be a bit repetitive at times. Driving long distances can become monotonous, but this is a minor issue compared to all the positive aspects of the game.

Overall, I highly recommend American Truck Simulator to anyone who enjoys simulation games or has an interest in truck driving. It is a well-crafted, realistic, and immersive experience that will keep you entertained for hours on end.

[b]American Truck Simulator pulls into the driving simulation genre, delivering a serene journey across the vast American landscape behind the wheel of a big rig.[/b]
[list]
[*]Realistic Trucking Experience: The game offers an immersive simulation with authentic truck handling, delivering a satisfying driving experience. (Pro)
[*]Scenic Landscapes: From the deserts of Nevada to the forests of Oregon, the game's visually stunning landscapes add depth and beauty to the journey. (Pro)
[*]Expansive Map: Covering a considerable portion of the U.S., the map provides diverse routes and scenic highways to explore. (Pro)
[*]Modding Support: The robust modding community adds an extra layer of customization, offering various truck models, weather mods, and additional maps. (Pro)
[*]Relaxing Gameplay: The laid-back nature of the game makes it ideal for unwinding and enjoying a calm, therapeutic driving experience. (Pro)
[*]Limited Variety: Despite the vastness of the map, some regions may feel repetitive or lack the variety of landscapes found in other driving simulators. (Con)
[*]Slow-Paced Progression: Progression can feel slow, and some players might find the initial phase of building their trucking empire somewhat tedious. (Con)
[*]Lack of Depth in Activities: Beyond the core trucking experience, the game could benefit from additional activities or more dynamic events. (Con)
[/list]
[b][i]In summary, American Truck Simulator offers a realistic and visually captivating trucking experience across the United States' diverse landscapes. With its immersive driving mechanics and serene gameplay, it's a solid choice for trucking enthusiasts seeking a relaxing journey. However, its limitations in regional variety, slow-paced progression, and lack of depth in additional activities might detract from the experience for some players.[/i][/b]

If you like driving games, well have I got one for you! ATS has so many things to do. The trucks are almost infinitely customizable, even with just the base items that the game gives you, never mind the extra goodies from the STEAM workshop and other places found on the world wide web thingy. And there are lots of trucks to choose from even in the base game, again not to mention the workshop mods. 

You can tailor your driving experience too, simulating everything from traffic offenses to needing to sleep, to how your truck handles. The choices are almost overwhelming, and many I have just left in default. Suspension stiffness, parking brakes, voice navigation are just a few of the many choices.

The base game gives you California, and the first two DLC's, Arizona and New Mexico, are free (i think, it's been a while...), and other states are added at a fairly regular clip, at a decent price too. It's not quite real time simulation, a game day will roll by in a couple hours at most. As far as I can tell, the game is set in summer, for I have yet to see snow or anything like that, but who knows, maybe that will get added. It does rain however, but you can set the percent chance in the game settings, from "Drought" to "Where's my ark?"

Overall, the game is great fun, and I've been playing a lot.

I bought this game for exclusive use in VR and i love it despite the pretty major flaws.

The things i really wish they would fix/add:

- Aliasing is REALLY bad in this, Some edges of objects look like strobe lights it's so bad. There needs to be a way to reduce aliasing more than it currently does. No other VR game of this quality has this problem. something CAN be done and it would make this game 100 x better in VR.

- VR implementation is very bare bones. Game runs in VR but that's about it. Everything else is done outside VR. I'd love a way to just perform simple actions in vr like turning my vehicle off and filling up gas. Even if it's menu based. Something where i wont have to raise my headset.

Outside of this the game is so good! You can toss on a podcast and play for hours and hours without even noticing.  It's hyper immersive as well. Sometimes you just catch yourself being fully immersed, like wait - I forgot im playing a game...It makes you forget what time it is.

For me, this game is one of my favorites.
Of course, some people will say "Why on earth should I drive from A to B?" or "There are much more exciting games than this!".

Well, that may well be the case.
But I have to say that the game has a calming effect, especially if you just want to relax.
Just enjoy the scenery, good music, nice rigs... and voil√†, a perfect day. 

The game is constantly being worked on to make it even better.
There are many places worth seeing in the game, for example famous buildings and national parks, which have a high recognition value.
Those who live in the USA, or in the states available in the game, will be able to confirm this.

Admittedly, for some time now, I've been discovering new things...
For example, every now and then the truck is spawned into another trailer, which causes you to be catapulted to the moon (fortunately, the moon has been available since the last update).
Of course, it is also possible that aliens try to abduct you, or that the moon's gravity is so strong that you are lifted upwards.
Of course, it can also happen that trailers and parked vehicles are spawned into each other and then blasted into space.

Maybe the bug will be fixed one fine day, or maybe not...
We may never know...

So, if you're looking for a good game and want to sit back and relax a little...

Well, this is the perfect game for you.

Have a relaxing ride everyone.

If you are a truck or trucking enthusiast, beware. This game has just enough reality to where you recognize trucks, towns, and landmarks, and just enough fantasy that it's fun to build your own trucking business from the ground up. Although I am a Cascadia man in real life, I've fallen in love with the Kenworth W900 and can't wait to grab the tuning pack to really build out my super heavy duty rig!

The only downside is that you'll want to build out your simulation rig to get the best experience possible. Great for gaming, bad for the wallet! The good news is that it's still playable on a mouse and keyboard. It's not a perfect immersion, but it's good enough to be fun. It reminds me of one of the first games I ever played, a Caterpillar simulator I played when I was 6 or 7 that I really wish I knew the name of... Anyways, go trucks.

Highly recommend, way more fun than actually trucking, great diversion from real life. Can't wait to expand to using a wheel, pedals, and shifter at some point.

I started off years ago playing a demo of SCS Software's Scania Truck Driving Simulator. Eventually, I evolved into Euro Truck Simulator 2. Once I started, I was hooked. Then, ATS finally came along, and I was hooked just as much. To me, this game is more of a relaxing thing for me. I've always been a fan of simulator games, but ATS definitely reached number one in my book on that. Between the graphic design of cities and states, to the realism of driving a tractor trailer, this game will literally get anyone hooked into it. I mostly play alone, but once in a while I'll do convoys with friends, and the excitement is just as good.

This game is so much fun! I've spent countless hours playing with no drop in enjoyment. The game gets even better with the addition of Workshop Mods. The creators of the mods really bring out the simulation in American Truck Simulator. Despite ATS coming out in 2016 it's still current through the consistent updates and DLCs, consisting of Trucks, Skins/Accessories, and States. If you decide to pick this game up you won't be disappointed.  PS. if you don't have a PC powerful enough to run this game I strongly recommend using NVIDIA GeForce Now. Use the Ultimate Membership.

this is by far my favorite driving game that i own it can run on lower power computers ok and look pretty good on higher power systems i do have a few gripes though like even when i play on my desktop with decent gpu power with high settings distant narrow objects look poor as if theres no aa and traffic lights are a big pain yes i realize its a simulation but every single last street light from Washington to new mexico  are always always red when i approach them and the wait time is incredibly unrealistic long every i mean every single intersection with an arrow will make you wait for the arrow no matter if there's cars or not and almost all arrows are leading arrows even in towns that dont use any leading aarows mind you I have been too a few of the towns in this game also the law i get a red light violation before i cross the line sometimes and the light not on violation tends to tick me off i have the automatic lights turned on but alas they dont work but i digress its just a video game and my complaints aside its a very good one a grinders paradise if i dont say so myself i think I have logged around 550+ hours on this game if you love drive simulators and big trucks this is definitely worth it one thousand percent recomend

Well, ATS and ETS are great... It's a wonderful truck simulator.
BUT there are some minuses:
 - it's a simulator, yap. Exactly truck simulator. Do you understand? There is nothing about modeling a real transportation company. Forget it, It is not tycoon. But if you would like to take a look (a very easy look) to the job of the truckers - you're welcome. You can even reduce default 'time zipping' to be possible feel what is it a real about. It's routine, Routine work. But, happily, by default (and you can even expand it) the game have 'time zipping' So you don't need to drive a week to go from one map corner to another. Same with salaries. I don't believe that this earnings are 'event' earings. It looks more like 'month earnings at this route'.
 - the second question: I did. I played the games of the team that created ATS and ETS. The core part of team created a great game 'Dalnoboyshiki'. That game was much more about fun, of course... But it had several advantages against ATS/ETS. The first one - is damage model. If you broke you lighst there is no lighs. Quite realistic, yeah? The same was for other systems. Now they provided an update that bringed part of it to the ATS. That's quite great! Yeah! BUT in that game you was able to see at the truck scheme which part is broken. In ATS and ETS it's, unfortunatelly, wasn't implemented. The damage icon is a 'progress bar', nothing more.
 - and last thing that make me feel 'buttheart': messages. "You want to sleep", "You ....". Why this messages overflow the f..... map? Oh, I know, I did something bad, or some important message. It's ok. BUT WHY I CANNOT SEE THE F*****NG MAP???? How should I follow route?????

PS I really likes this game, even with this problem.
PPS and yes, I wrote this review because of my 'buttheart" on the last problem.

Coming up to one-hundred hours of trucking, whilst going through my game collection I decided to leave some reviews. This 2016 trucking simulation still receives updates and DLC's which shows the SCS Software takes pride in their project. I use a wheel and peddles which really levels up the experience and captivates the trucking culture. The seasonal events such as 2023's vampire World Of Trucks plushie was a fun communal event to contribute to with the rewards being able to be used in both ATS and ETS. Managing your own business, hiring employees and providing them with trucks is a fun way of presenting passive income whilst you hit the states of America yourself. 

As from my one-hundred hours of playing with my wheel and peddles, I can not suggest this experience more, especially with friends!

Very realistic. For years I have been looking for a game where I could drive the American Highways, in fact i used to do Google Maps street view to cruise the highways of the United States. One day my friend told me about this game and he showed me the route from Las Cruces, NM to Portland, OR which was a route I have done on google maps street view and the scenery was very realistic. Of Course it wasn't to scale but the main landmarks that I remember were there. When I finally had the money to get the game I got the enchanted pack which included the base game and New Mexico and I now have every state avaliable in the game. If you love driving and you love roadtrips, this is the game for you. infact there could be a huge chance your hometown is included if you live in the western United States. amazing game i would rate it a 9/10 mostly because it dosent include certain routes that I feel would make more sence but other than that its very realistic

well... so i got the game cause i like games like this (not some people tho).. The game is good (maybe better than the wife you have MAYBE i SAID MAYBE!)
 Don't get me wrong, BUT like (the marriage) it's got some issues.. The fine and traffic violation system is completely Fu**ed (unlike a marriage with a bad person where there is NO fu**ed going on). 

You WILL get fined for doing nothing wrong (like a wife blaming you for something you didnt do). Got a car that some npc rams into you on a merging lane when your in front of him YOU get the FINE. 

You got a another car that SPEEDs up to get past you on a merging lane and suddenly stops in the middle and it get swiped by your trailer's end corner YOU get the FINE. (much like getting slapped) you see the light turned green 50 feet before you get to the intersection and you just go through cause you know green means go! you get a traffic violation for running a red light on green.. 

Or you are in a turning lane (or doing something for your wife cause TOLD you) to turn left you got your blinker on then your light turns green you start to make your left turn (or go when your wife tells you to go) and you are hit with a fine (or slap) telling you that you ran a red light when it was green and not even yellow AGAIN your fault for following the rules of a wife (or a out of control fines system) don't see much difference between the 2) who wants nothing more than to make your life hard with no logic and (ESPECIALLY no REASONING) to it at all.

So you're sleepy and you're 10 miles from the drop off point and the game charge you 400 dollars when the game knows there is not resting area nearby YOU STILL get FINED. and like a demanding wife she will nag at you CONSTANTLY to get some sleep knowing again there are no places to sleep the gets mad when you can't sleep (which she knows). Unlike real life (in a truck you CAN pull out to the side of a the road) to the game wont left you for some reason.. I guess devs are scared their rest areas (like the wife) will be labeled useless so they both conspire to make it so you can't do some things that would be considered NORMAL.

You'er at a stop light and STOPPED and the car rear ends you. Guess what? YOU GET THE FINE. its like being married to a gold digger.. Nothing is ever good enough for this person or the FINES system. It feels like you are blamed for everything much like a person who wants attention OR money but she forgot she already drained you dry that month but makes you pay the fees anyway to her. 

I do think the game may make up fees if you don't get any in a long while (much like a wife expecting you to cheat then finds out there is no cheating so she makes something up and bashed our your tail light then claims you have a busted light). Its like trying to find out the mood your wife is in when she is yelling from the next room, and it leaves you wondering if you're betting off pretending to sleep or jumping out the window or taking the risk of answering afraid of what she might want this time. 

If your marriage (or game) sounds like this you are a victim! don't just sit silently and take the abuse from her (or the fine system) speak up and do something about it!  

P.S. don't buy flowers for this game they won't work.. Flowers might work on your wife for a day or 2 but not for this game! I'm willing to bet the game will fine you for the flowers if you did..

P.S.S. unlike a marriage you can turn off the finicky wife fines in the game options menu so playing the game now is less stressful than being married to a person with compromised values. Also you can turn off sleep.

Surprisingly good and addictive. I bought it on sale for under $10 and was surprised by how much I enjoyed it.

The premise is simple, pick up some cargo and take it somewhere. Graphics are slightly dated (it is an older game after all). Trucks look gorgeous, cars look OK, scenery is nice enough though some config file tweaking is required to reduce pop-in. The game is generous with money, which you can spend to buy more trucks, hire drivers, or bling out your current ride with various customization options. There is a ton of options to customize your gameplay experience too, from "I want to drive a gigantic golf cart and not be punished for ramming cars off the road" to "I have a full virtual driving setup with a wheel, pedals and a shifter and want to feel as close to the real thing without needing a CDL".

There are some issues of course:

- There is no damage modeling. You could drive into a concrete wall going 200 miles per hour and your truck would just bounce off and a message will inform you of how much damage you took, in percent.

- AI traffic can be brain-dead or irrationally aggressive, which results in crashes and fines (if you enable them that is).

- Upgrades (cosmetic and performance) are gated behind XP levels. While money is relatively easy to come by, XP gain can be a bit of a grind.

- Some trucks have a dizzying amount of customization options (i.e. Kenworth W900) while others barely have any, without resorting to mods.

All in all it's a solid game despite the issues, and the devs still support it and release new maps every so often (however, those aren't free).

The beauty of the Trucking Simulator games from SCS is you can play them in so many different ways.  Sometimes I just chill and play on a single monitor, sometimes I multi screen it, but my favorite way is to play with the QoL and realism mods on my VR headset.  It's just as fun with a xbox control as it is with a steering wheel.  You literally feel like you are driving down the road in a rig. 

The only negative things I can say are small.  When playing in vr it takes a little tweaking to get the Route Advisor out of the way. Also you can't read the signs unless you run your computer to death maxxing out the texture upscaling. 

Basic issues (more room for improvement) is Audio mixing.  The sounds are great just not balanced.  Second is the AI pathing.  The only reason i bring it up is that you get sooo immersed that it's kind of jarring when it happens.

I like the realism of the game.  There is not anything I can think of that I don't like about it. I have already recommended the game to several people.

I really enjoy this game. It very much is reminiscent of playing 18 Wheels of Steel when I was younger. I don't play much online so I can't say much for the community of this game. The graphics are excellent even though I'm playing on my laptop, the base game is more than enough to keep you busy, which is good because the DLCs that are sold make up for the other 90% of what this game could be. I do find it unfortunate that there are so many DLCs that end up surpassing the cost of the game by a longshot. I've played the base game for 50 hours and have started getting some of the DLCs, I just wish you got more for the initial price, rather than paying the cost of the game 4 more times to travel further east.

The actual customization of your trucks within this game is excellent. I wish they could add a few things but whats included is pretty impressive. The game lets you change just about anything you want on the truck. Don't like one style air horn? You have 5 more. Don't like those parking lights? You can change them too. Want more trailer lights? You got it. What do I wish they added? Just a little bit more. You can't have a long frame with a day cab on your Pete. Want a long nose? Never heard of it. Fiberglass fenders? You can get rid of your fenders, but you can't add them. Any type of aftermarket part? Only off the shelf dealer parts. I just wish the devs would look through a Berube's magazine and add the parts in there. There are so many more opportunities they aren't taking advantage of.

The truck selection that you can get is great, many models from multiple brands. Once again though, I just wish they'd add more. They added used trucks, but I wish they would add old trucks. Nothing would beat an 80's Mack Superliner or an old KW Needlenose. If they added a section to the used truck market for trucks like those I would be ecstatic. Building a fleet of new trucks is one thing, I just wish I could add a few pieces of old iron to my lineup. Most trucking companies don't start out with a brand new Pete, KW, or Mack, they start with something with miles already on it. Something older, mechanical, missing the push button auto trans, and with good rumble. I want something that takes 4 business days to go 30 mph. Something that looks cool as it pulls a way overweight low-bed down the highway that I know I don't have the brakes to stop. The Mack R series, a Superliner, a cab over KW, something with character. New trucks are cool, but I wish I had something older as well.

All in all, this game is great. 9/10 fr fr
the best simulator game ive played in my life well done guys ty

I've had this product for a few years I would say, and I'm just finally getting around to doing a review.

So, to simply put, this game is wonderful. It does have its occasional crashes (usually only when updates come about, but they're usually fixed in decent of time on both the devs and modders end), but that could on the users end, more than likely. I love that this map keeps getting expanded on a periodic basis and hope that someday it will reach the east coast. The scenery is something of a wonder to look at. So incredibly relaxing to play this game. Only thing about this game, is it makes me wish the Devs also took on Long Distance Bus Simulation, which I think they could do with relative ease, albeit with certain mechanics changed and adding passenger AI, fare/ticket collection. I hope they do decide to tackle it at some point, if they have the chance and the resources to do it. 

But, as of now, they're doing a fantastic job with this as well as the ETS version.

Highly recommend to anyone interested in driving simulation games.

I bought ATS to give it a try since I had aspirations to become a truck driver long ago. The menus and user interface are easy to navigate and the tutorial was helpful. The graphics are good and with the 1.49 update, the night sky now has stars and the moon to add further immersion to the game. As a suggestion for a future update, the devs need to add a feature to where the semis get dirty over time to increase realism and game immersion. It's kind of weird that my semi would show up at a destination after a 1000+ mile trip and still look clean.   
The AI traffic in game can be wonky sometimes. An example would be when I pull out onto a road, it appeared that the AI cars didn't see a big semi pulling out onto the road and proceeded to hit me. Not once, but twice! Somehow, it was my fault and got charged for the accident. There was one time where there was a traffic jam caused by a semi trying to turn but a utility truck was in the semi's way. At first I thought I'd be stuck there, but the game had a humorous way of solving the traffic jam. It clipped the utility truck into the road while moving it back so that the semi could finish the turn. Then, the utility truck was put into the air, then back onto the road and traffic started moving again.
During game play, I noticed certain sections of road had weird changes in speed limits. One particular section, is a section on the north side just outside of Tonopah, NV where the speed limit goes from 25mph to 70mph for a brief time then down to 35mph. This isn't the only section of road that has these radical changes in speed limits though. 
All in all, I'd recommend this game to people who have or had aspirations to become a truck driver. It's fun and the AI traffic can be hilarious at times. However, there is one slight irritation with this game and that's the rest stop feature if you have the "fatigue-O-meter" turned on. Apparently, it's been a known problem for a hot minute. When you need to rest, you have to pull into a rest stop to attain rest. Unfortunately, there's no marker indicating where you can park your truck and rest. Markers for refueling, weigh station, repair shop, taking jobs, etc with a green marker for you drive into to give the prompt for refueling, vehicle inspections, etc. For some reason, there is no green location marker for resting at rest stops. You just drive to the spot according to your GPS and hope you get the prompt to rest. Unfortunately, I had multiple issues where I drive to the spot on the GPS and there's no prompt to rest to the point that I had to disable the "fatigue-O-meter".
Other than what was mentioned above, it's still a good, fun game.

I was very excited to hear a Kansas expansion was coming....unfortunately it falls way short in value and realism. The first run from KC to Junction lacked many significant aspects of that route. Where is the airfield off the highway before JC, where is the actual town of JC that exists before the exit you all had me exit? It's a decent update, but it's worth less than $10.

After spending 419 hours in this game, I can say I enjoyed it a bunch before I was a truck driver and now that I am one, it is even better of a game.  You can visit so many cities and locations and some may seem very familiar to you if you live in one of those types of places.  I can't talk much on the weather update released with 1.49 but some Dynamic Weather would be AMAZING for this game.  Mods can be your best friend from the Workshop, there are so many selections and options of different things like chicken lights and strobes and different trailers. 

Be weary of 3rd party a.k.a. not mods from the steam workshop.  There are many great ones out there but there are many that are just bad websites. 

Anyways, you can truck via single player and enjoy all the trips solo, you can play TruckersMP with a bunch of people from all over the world and you can play in a Convoy with a friend that hosts it and you can all run the same mods and enjoy your custom trucks and trailers together.

This game is very playable on a controller but I would 1000% suggest a wheel and pedal setup!  Also, if you do get a wheel and pedal setup, the force feedback wheels like Logitech sells work great, you can adjust the settings to feel every pump in the road, you can adjust the stability of the truck/trailer you make driving more challenging.

A good friend got me into roads, racing and driving in general, and this game delivers that almost in-explainable feeling of joy from just.. driving. Cruising on open roads, listening to music, getting from one place to another, crossing state lines, appreciating all the various traffic rules of each state.. Driving irl makes you realize just how big this country, heck this world is. I felt that for the first time driving on my way to Washington State, which was my first ever trip outside of my own state. It was an experience I truly loved, and this game captures that feeling perfectly well. I can drive that exact route, albeit a much small scaled one, and it's fun to experience other states I've never driven through before. It's awesome.

This game is an all-time favorite of mine as a fan of therapeutic and slow-paced real-world sims I find myself bouncing between ATS and Farming Simulator. I come from a trucking family and have a background in Diesel Mechanics and this game scratches the itch to drive and customize trucks that I can't get anywhere else. 

The studio constantly updates the older game maps and is consistently releasing new maps (I can't wait till they get to the southeast). There are lots of great mods for newer trucks and plenty of old-school trucks and paint jobs. The progression of owning your own trucking company keeps this game fresh, with the ability to buy garages, hire drivers, and update their trucks, I have never had a time where I have had millions in the bank and ended up bored. Even if you take a break for a while you can almost always come back with the hopes of new updates, new cargo, and mods. The variety of trucks and customization open up a door for this game to take all your free time. I have 200 hours plus in this game and generally only get in a few hours a week of gaming. Buy this game and support a company that cares for its players and actually improves on their product!

Currently writing this with 86k on my W900. Overall, this game is pretty good as it goes for US based truck sims. The framerate in older areas or high density areas isn't that good on older cards, but overall your framerate will be above 30 90% of the time if you're using an older card such as a RX 580. IIRC I did see a devblog about possibly modifying the game engine to enable multithreading to help with performance. 

DLC - 90% of the skin DLCs I don't have, however I can say, that only playing the base game and not getting the state DLCs, you are missing out on longer drives that you could be taking, especially once this game crosses the Mississippi. However, I would argue that SCS does maybe overprice these DLCs, and they could maybe like, every 6 from the release of the DLC months drop like, a dollar off the DLCs to a minimum of $5, or maybe start bundling some of these more empty states such upcoming North and South Dakota.

Damage model - I do like that, for minor damage the transmission/engine damage have been unlinked from Cabin damage, so this allows you to bump into AIs more often without fear of loosing transmission gears, also, I do suggest within like your first hour of gameplay, just turn off traffic offenses and leave it off, the AI has bricks for brains and will just randomly bump into you, or get in your way, or turn into you. I have yet to get to permanent wear on my truck, I can only see this happening if I just drive more.

Stuff that should be added to the game

I would really like it to tell me if I have driven a specific route before. I'd like to know before taking a driving contract if I have already taken a double container with transformers from Carson City, NV to Havre, MT, that would be nice to know before driving it again.

I would also like for it to tell me what states my trailer combo is legal in, instead of telling me that the when I arrive to the garage screen that XYZ trailer isn't legal unless you stuff it into a garage in ABC state.

I'll edit this if I think of things to post, but these are my thoughts for now.

The older this game gets the better it gets.  

The constant updating and working on perfecting the overall experience is worth getting this game.  There is a constant flow of DLC and updates which shows the developers commitment to the game.  Unlike a lot of games, the DLC is reasonably priced and it does not feel like SCS is trying to take advantage of it's players.; unlike some companies. Plus - they listen to the players and give them what they want.  Along with an outstanding modding community this game is worth it for that alone.   

The game play itself is as close to real life as one can get.  With the bonus of it not having to be real life.  There are so many tweaks the game can be played however you wish. 

With the game always on sale it is worth the pick up.  However, it is worth full price.  It is costly with all the DLC but pick and choose.  With all the mods out there, I would recommend getting the maps first.  This will give you the most options for your trucking journeys.  

After that the heavy cargo and special transport which give extra things to carry and special missions which transporting things like massive helicopters and huge boats.

The rest is up to you and how you want to play the game.  Just get the game and play it, you won't be disappointed.

Honestly? ATS  was the reason I was able to discover my knack and love for trucking. I have logged quite a few hours of endlessly staring at a screen learning how to move a truck in theory.. I was given the opportunity to try for my Class A Commercial Driver License through the company I work for.

Today, because of ATS, I passed my driving test almost flawlessly, and my backing techniques without a point. The moment I stepped into a truck in real life I felt fairly comfortable. Nervous at first, but I already had a strong grasp of how I needed to make my big rig move. I flew through my CDL courses with flying colors. 

Thank you to the developers of ATS. If trucking is something you're passionate about, i'd definitely buy this game!

I mean, if you like trucks and you like to simulate this is definitely the game for you! Once you have played the game long enough you notice there are a lot of things that are repetitive but with the additional new states that have been added at least the roads and scenery stay a bit fresh. They also add new trucks from time to time which has been great although I prefer sticking to my Western Star and make the lowly peons drive other things like Freightliner and such. My only real problems with the game are probably based more on licensing and such, things like damage. It would be nice if trucks experienced certain random failures or maybe you bought the perfect truck that has no issues for thousands and thousands of miles but it would be cool if you had the 'problem' truck occasionally or that due to your roughness in driving you wear out the transmission or maybe overloading overtaxed certain things. I also would still love to see my other trucks on the road maybe even carrying my logo like in games I played when I was younger (Hard Truck 2) and I would also rather invisible walls to some extent be removed. It would be nice if there were an easy way to have all roads mapped and scaled into the game so that we could drive on all of them and maybe 'drive to our real homes' for instance if we so choose. Imagine if somehow through online maps and overhead views they generated the roads and actual homes into the game. I just think that would be cool but I imagine way harder than meets the eye. Things like weather actually following real trends.

All in all though, positive experience and very, very playable and addicting, you can certainly lose track of time playing this game. I also want to note I only play without mods. There are decent mods available I have seen through watching random videos but I prefer the experience delivered by the developers.

For a couple of dollars on sale it's a nice pick up at first glance, I honestly did not think I would enjoy this game as much as I have while spending time in it the last week or so, so where to start? 

First off, The game is primarily keyboard and accessory accessible. (Wheel, HShift, Tobi) There are maps for controllers on Steam Overlay that unfortunately, habitually seem to be spontaneously switching between supported and non supported controls, this makes it very tedious as sometimes there is vibrations from the road and premapped layouts for the buttons, sometimes there is not, leaving you one day driving one way and another a completely different. (Sometimes my joysticks are detected and not just the buttons, so I can use the right stick as a camera and turn in a sort of 'chase-cam' mode, Other times, I am forced to awkwardly use my mouse to turn my camera while I am driving with the controller, it makes me think I should just use the keyboard sometimes as I wind up having to do half of the controls on it anyways since the mapping is sometimes just...not there...?) 

Now lets talk about things outside of the controls: 

Graphics :
6.9/10 The graphics are passable, Nothing Crazy, But cosmetics are cleanly identifiable and some of the backdrops/events are pretty well done.

Gameplay : 7.5/10
Traffic responds "Okay" in most instances, Or as you would expect them to for the most part. The setting/environment depending on location is Semi-Immersive. ( :^) ) The game seems, Small upon base edition/base collectors pack once you do an adequate amount of runs, however, there are frequent sales and picking up x4-6 maps for 12-18 isn't 'such' a bad deal and it opens up many alternate "playstyles"/routes. The external DLC's for shipping/cargo are a unique twist on regular game play that open up a field of reliance that makes the game seem less at-your-own-pace/casual demand to the "Regular" type of runs. (Learning how to transport a Turn-Key House in one piece, Which roads are most efficient for lighter or heavier weights, Widths, How to carry them and what to use differently etc.) 

The game is fun with more people, I'd highly recommend it as a casual game to play with friends when you don't want to do something more demanding.

Physics/AI Reactions: 6.5/10

P1 : Momentum and breaking physics, as well as most of the basic driving physics are relatively well done. (From my PoV, Driving in Assisted Automatic instead of full.) However, there is much work to be done, I do not think moisture/rain effects or traction control are in a state that can be defined as actually "Finished" as they both unfortunately cause very similar reactions with little room for differentiation that makes displacement feel like it doesn't really 'matter' if it's raining or not/if you lose traction on one function as opposed to another excluding certain accessories. Gravel and loose terrain though visually different appear to also react like pavement/tarmac. 

P2: The AI Reactions and registration of penalty is, questionable. There are many circumstances when I am through a yellow light and get a red light violation, or am turning in the correct turn lane on a green arrow and crossing the stop line triggers the main lane lights. Speeding violations also require a longer window because when I hit a 40 from a 60-70 there's essentially no way for me to slow myself down excluding a full stop or brake lock should there be a cop on the road in adequate time, even with smaller trucks and tiny loads.  I am looking forward to a traffic update, the new events/road traffic spots are very cool but I come across "a(i)ccidents" that are not event based frequently where there are just 6-15 cars stopped in the middle of a freeway not moving for no apparent reason on both solo playthroughs and during Convoy's and it is EXTREMELY tedious to be going the speed limit on a freeway and then suddenly the traffic infront of you just stops and forces you to thread a near impossible needle and chance wrecking your truck/load or alternatively hope your parking brake and E brake stop you in time to not wreck your load anyways. 


Ultimate rating: 6.5/10 (B-) 

A good game, Just above the average enjoyment for a typically budgeted time sink. There will likely be consistent content until the completion of the game and the 48 or so of the 50 (Alaska/Hawaii being unlikely considering they are not mainland states) states are included (?) which potentially makes it something one could revisit from time to time.

I bought this game on a whim a few months ago, and I think it's safe to say I love it. I don't have the time or money to see as much of the country as I'd like, and this game scratches that itch just right. I can drive some of the most iconic trucks to iconic and historic United States Cities, it's perfect for someone who likes history, architecture, and geography. One thing I'd like to add is changing seasons, it would make Colorado just that little bit better to see it under snow. All in all, this game is perfect, whether or not you own one of the steering wheel peripherals. I have to admit that I think the CDL advertisements in game are pretty goofy, I like them.

This game is great in that you can take it as serious or jokingly as you like. If you do take it serious then you will find that a lot of truck systems are (as far as I can tell) accurately modeled and has the proper affect you'd assume it would. There's a straightforward skill tree to unlock and this lets you do ever higher rewarding jobs and take bigger cargo for longer meaning you get paid more which lets you hire more drivers and buy more trucks and trailers and expand your trucking empire. The traffic laws and regulations are also implemented in game and realistically restricts the kind of trailer combinations you can haul depending on the states laws. 

Alternatively if that doesn't sound fun you can turn the radio up to max, pick any random job and ignore every single road law possible.

Look no further, as time will fly while you make your way across the countryside moving goods from one place to another, seeing the sights along the way.  Predicting the silly ways that AI traffic will behave adds a challenge to getting on and off the highways safely, but once you are out on the open road, not much will be stopping you from becoming king of the road.  Additionally, with new content continuing to be released periodically, there is no shortage of game play for those needing to take a load off.  Furthermore, with the added in-game advertising for actual trucking companies, some may find an opportunity to make their hobby into a profession if they can stomach the lifestyle.

In this game, you create your own trucking company and deliver various goods to multiple states in the USA. Currently on the map are Arizona, California, Colorado, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Oregon, Texas, Utah, Washington. and Wyoming (with Kansas coming in 2023). Watch out for crashes because they take out a lot of money for repairs. Also, keep watch on your speed because the police are watching and will give tickets for traffic offenses.

Amazing game... Every time a new DLC comes out I love it even more... Sure there are more things that they could do with the game, like adding in the ability to drive smaller trucks and make deliveries like box trucks, flat beds, or even pickups but even without those things this game is amazing. I love sitting back and just driving, it is super relaxing. If you have a steering wheel that is the best, but if not then pick up a controller (PS4 of Xbox - get one at a pawn shop they are fairly cheap), it will make a world of difference even having a controller over the keyboard and mouse.

**EDIT** 11/2022
This game continues to grow and improve and simply continue to raise the bar on the this amazing truck driving simulator experience. This year they have released 2 more states and just announced the next one. SCS is clearly devoted to making ATS an amazing game that includes the whole of the USA.

**EDIT** 11/2023
SCS continues to do an amazing job adding additional content but also going back and upgrading and adding things to previous content that needs to be updated or is worth adding. Keep up the great work!

I don't have much to say other than it's exactly what it looks like. Driving big rigs for many hours at a time. The fun of it comes from its simplicity, someone who knows nothing about trucks can play it and understand it. However, it also has advanced features and touches like being able to change the suspension and driveshaft torque. Pair that with a wheel and shifter, and you have a great time ahead of you. Also, the maps are very beautiful, specifically the newer map dlcs, and although most of the states are paid, if you get invested in this game, it's a small price to pay (especially on sale!).

Absolutely love this game. I have played truck simulators for years, but this one is the best I've played. The level of detail is superb. This game is a definite must-have in your collection. Even if it is your first time playing simulation games, you are going to like it.

Rating: üëçüëçüëçüëçüëç (Thumbs up, pedal to the metal!)

American Truck Simulator (ATS) is not just a game; it's a red, white, and blue symphony of trucking excellence that has made me appreciate the vastness of the American landscape. As someone who once struggled to pronounce "Albuquerque," I can now confidently navigate its streets and many more.

The graphics are a testament to the beauty of the American terrain, from the deserts of Arizona to the evergreen forests of Oregon. I find myself marvelling at the landscapes as if I were on a cross-country road trip, minus the bathroom breaks.

The attention to detail is impeccable, capturing the essence of American trucks with an authenticity that makes me feel like I've joined the ranks of the nation's trucking elite. The sprawling highways, iconic landmarks, and diverse cities make each delivery feel like a patriotic mission ‚Äì I'm not just hauling cargo; I'm delivering freedom.

The unintentional masterpieces continue in ATS, where my tire tracks have unintentionally outlined the contours of the Grand Canyon or formed an accidental tribute to the Statue of Liberty. Move over, GPS ‚Äì I've got a paintbrush called a semi-truck.

The radio stations provide the perfect soundtrack to my American trucking adventure. Whether I'm rolling through the heartland to country tunes or cruising through the city lights with some good ol' rock and roll, ATS knows how to keep my wheels turning and my spirits high.

In conclusion, American Truck Simulator is more than a game; it's a celebration of the vast, diverse landscapes that make up this great nation. Thumbs up, pedal to the metal, and a tip of the trucker hat to the developers at SCS Software for creating a masterpiece that turned me into a star-spangled road warrior.

I drive a truck for a living, and some people might find it strange that I come back home and essentially play job simulator. But its actually a really fun job. I enjoy ATS because it allows me to enjoy the road without all the annoying hassles of driving IRL like worrying about traffic, following distances, waiting at stop lights, speed limits, etc. It's just pure driving joy with none of the headache. SCS has really poured a lot of labor into ATS since it released. Trucks feel very weighty, graphics are really pretty, sounds have improved considerably. Driving on the highway feels very tranquil, peaceful, and you just lose yourself. I have zero complaints with the game, I just hope they keep adding more and more states. Its a really deep rich game and I love making money and buying more trucks, coloring each one uniquely and investing in a driver that I keep forever. The game esseentially captures all that is great about trucking with none of the annoyances or stupid stuff. It does have all the "simulation" aspects for those of us who want to simulate, like weigh stations, tickets, fines, road rules etc. 

It's just freedom at its finest. I love it.

Edit 11/24/23: still the best driving game of all time

American Truck Simulator (ATS) is nothing short of a masterpiece in the world of simulation gaming. As an avid fan of the genre, I can confidently say that ATS has raised the bar to new heights, delivering an unparalleled trucking experience that combines realism, attention to detail, and sheer joy.

From the moment you hit the road in your meticulously recreated truck, the attention to detail is simply breathtaking. The landscapes of the United States are beautifully rendered, capturing the essence of each region with stunning accuracy. Whether you're navigating the bustling streets of Los Angeles, cruising through the vast deserts of Nevada, or winding your way through the majestic Rockies, every mile is a visual treat.

The realism extends beyond the visuals. The sound design in ATS is exceptional, with the hum of your engine, the rhythmic clunk of your gears, and the ambient sounds of the environment immersing you completely in the trucker's world. The attention to detail is so precise that you can almost feel the weight of your cargo as you navigate the highways and byways.

One of the standout features of ATS is its commitment to authenticity. The fleet of trucks available is a dream for enthusiasts, meticulously modeled after their real-world counterparts. The handling of each vehicle feels true to life, requiring a delicate balance of skill and precision to navigate the diverse terrains. The inclusion of realistic weather conditions and day-night cycles adds another layer of challenge and immersion, making each journey a unique experience.

The open-world design of American Truck Simulator is a triumph, offering a vast and interconnected network of roads and cities to explore. The sense of freedom is exhilarating, allowing players to chart their own course, take on different jobs, and build their trucking empire. The economy and progression systems are well-balanced, providing a satisfying sense of accomplishment as you upgrade your rig and expand your business.

The community support for ATS is another commendable aspect. The modding community has flourished, creating a wealth of additional content that enhances and expands upon the already rich gameplay. From new trucks and trailers to custom map expansions, the mods contribute to the longevity of the game and keep the experience fresh for veterans and newcomers alike.

In conclusion, American Truck Simulator is a triumph in the world of simulation gaming. Its commitment to realism, attention to detail, and the sheer joy of trucking make it a must-play for fans of the genre. Whether you're a seasoned truck simulator veteran or a newcomer looking for a unique and immersive gaming experience, ATS delivers on all fronts Also more so then any other quality above the devs always active!

If you have issues running the game do this:
navigate to C:\Users\username\Documents\American Truck Simulator and open the config.cfg with a text editor ( for example Notepad). Once opened, scroll to the bottom and look for the line uset cf_asus_aura "1" and change 1 to 0 and save the file.

Honestly one of my favorite games on Steam. ATS and its counterpart ETS2 are both amazing games to play while relaxing. SCS as a company is transparent to their players, and always open to feedback, and implementing things off of that feedback regularly. ATS and ETS2 are some of the only games where I will buy the DLC at full price purely because of the amount of hours I have in game, but also because I just want to support SCS themselves as much as I can. Major updates, although sporadic, are always well thought through, and comprehensive without breaking the game, or gameplay.
Additionally, there is a wealth of mods available for the game, both on the Steam workshop, and paid mods around the internet. Speaking of mods, SCS does not discourage the use of mods, and allows players to get their achievements whether mods are in use or not, which, honestly is a really nice touch. Outside of the standard game, you can play online, either with friends in the convoy mode, or by yourself by connecting your profile to World of Trucks (WoT). Furthermore, the whole community around the game is a wonderful group of people, and that can only be a testament to the wonderful folks at SCS and WoT.

TLDR
9.5/10 definitely recommend

(the .5 deduction is for the frame drops and stutters in ATS, which SCS are aware of, and have announced that they have actively been working to solve the problem, a mild annoyance for sure, but absolutely does not tarnish the game in its entirety)

Welcome to American Truck Simulator, where the great American road is your playground and a big rig is your toy. This isn't just a game, it's a love letter to the open road, where every highway is a story and every delivery is a mini-adventure.

What's the vibe? It's chill with a side of thrill. You're in the driver's seat, juggling the zen of a quiet drive with the buzz of making it to your destination on time. It's like playing Tetris, but the blocks are 40 tons and have a horn.

In a nutshell, ATS is part game, part travelogue, and all about the joy of the journey. Relax, enjoy the sights and feel oddly accomplished after a successful delivery. Buckle up, start your engine, and hit the open road!

One of the most relaxing driving games. 

It's nice, it has good graphics, the states are well made and the optimization is also good. This game allows you to tweak a lot of things to make it more of your likeness.

You can customize the trucks from inside to outside with a lot of options + third-party mods.
You can choose where you want to work and what kind of products you want to ship, buy different garages, and so on. You can even disable some simulation mechanics. There is a lot of configuration you can make out of the box in this game.

Also, you don't need a wheel and pedals to have fun in this game, you can have a great time with just a controller, It's greatly configured for that. The feeling might be better with a wheel setup though. But still, very good with just a controller or even with keyboard and mouse. I play with a controller and I always enjoy it.

Still unsure? Download the demo and test it by yourself. I also recommend watching a gameplay video without commentary so you can feel the game and make your own opinion on it.

Overall, It's very good for those looking for a relaxing driving game I also love that this game contains nice modding support which enhances the experience even more.
