Anyways, 
Coming from games like 18 Wheels of Steel American Long Haul, American Truck Simulator is a welcome modern take on the open roads of the United States. Attention to detail seems important to the developers for getting routes and landscapes just right. The driving experience feels authentic down to even getting cut off in traffic forcing you to brake to almost a standstill with a heavy load just before going up a hill with zero acceleration and the guy behind you honking because you're going 25 in an 80. Graphics seem very good, and although the animation of people and animals may not always look the smoothest it doesn't really matter when you're blowing passed them at 10mph over the speed limit with an 80,000 pound load. The handling of the truck feels very realistic. There are a few things that seem unrealistic, like speeding passed road blockers with police handling a traffic collision without any consequences, but it's either that or back track a few hundred miles for another route and I am not doing that. I do enjoy that the police aren't watching me like big brother and ready to pounce on me with infractions every second although I have had a few tickets. I actually feel like there is a lot of freedom on the open road to get your late shipments delivered on time which makes the realism of passing a cop and panic to slow down really hit home. Online radio streaming in game seems to be my favorite aspect, I don't know why I enjoy talk radio so much while driving cross country but it's wonderful. Versus 18 Wheels of Steel where you needed to add your own music to game files to make a playlist, which this game offers too but who has music files these days in the modern streaming world? I think some in game Spotify account link would make more sense, but then again on PC you can just play Spotify in the background anyway so! I don't know. The online steaming options are good and add a lot of immersion and help me stay up to date on current events and listening to real radio DJs chatting is a nice addition. Anyway, all in all I think this game is genuinely wonderful. As a forward deployed service member who misses home now and then, I'm looking forward to the rest of the United States added as DLC. I hope the developers continue to hone the details and add more content and destinations. Their dedicated research teams taking road trips in the US to help give feedback and realism to the game is a nice touch and frankly I am jealous of them having such a job. I hope every DLC purchase fuels the research teams to explore more states to be added into the game! Patiently waiting for Missouri, Iowa, and Illinois myself. My hopes are that long term goals include parts of Canada and Mexico but I will be happy if they don't give up on the rest of the mainland US. If parts of Canada could be added, then Alaska would have to be next! Ice Road Truckers DLC? What beautiful scenery. Other ideas I have include the ability to purchase cars to take road trips and sight see once you're a rich CEO of you're own business or the ability to walk around for more photo ops. But I'll quit dreaming. 

I want to encourage the ATS team to keep going! Don't give up on this project. I hope you find enough success in it to keep it going to add more and more! It's a great simulator. I find it to be the most addicting and relaxing game to play after a long day and gives me a taste of home. I'm excited to see how far this game can be taken. How many small towns and rural areas could be added to give more routes and short cuts? What other content can be added so the millions made in the trucking business can be used to continue gameplay to keep things interesting? 
It's a game worth playing and worth continuing development! I will happily support the team with every DLC purchase that gets released. It's worth it. I'm looking forward to my free CDL after playing this game for many hours.
looking forward to going from Cali to Maine one day

As one of the three individuals who live in the state Wyoming, it was a real treat to see some familiar places on the roadways. Honestly didn't expect any dev team anywhere to invest time and resources into recreating parts of Wyoming that weren't Yellowstone, and the fact that SCS did was unironically one of the reasons I wanted to try out the game. Best part is of course, I got more than just easter eggs for a Wyomingite. A whole lot more. This is a great game!

[h3]Note:[/h3]
I've edited this review many times over the years. My initial review was at 843 hours. 1st edit at 1,738, 2+ years after release. 2nd edit at 2,495, 4+ years. 3rd edit at 3,120, few months ago. This is my 4th edit at 3,171, ~6 years after release. This'll likely be my final edit refining the review. It'll be long. Easily my favorite game & dev of all time. I wish to do them justice w/ this review.

[h3]The Devs[/h3]
First & foremost, I want to talk about SCS Software, the devs. SCS cares deeply about the community & their games. They listen to & interact w/ the community. They listen to feedback & act on it very often. Some feedback takes longer to act on than others, but the majority of reasonable feedback is heard & addressed. They steadily release new, quality content to keep the game fresh. In between content updates, there's hundreds of mods releasing, so you always have something new to try.

To this day, you'll see people complain there "isn't enough content" or they "want new trucks or maps RIGHT NOW". These people forget what happens when stuff is rushed. When care & quality are thrown away in favor of speed & quantity. Well... Look at all the AAA games & DLC coming out severely unfinished w/ many bugs, game-breaking issues, & complete lack of basic features. This is where SCS differs greatly & what makes them stand apart from AAA studios in many ways.

SCS creates quality content. They take their time w/ whatever they're working on. So much of what they add is completely free of charge too, including new trucks. E.g, a decent amount of content in updates for a map expansion launch, is free to all players. Updates for an expansion launch consist of more than just support for the expansion. Those updates add new companies (where applicable), cargoes, features, & improvements which are added to the base game. Even if you don't buy expansions, you're still getting new content, just from updates that accompany expansion launches. The only paid content after buying the base game are map expansions, paint jobs, occasional specialized cargo DLCs, vehicle tuning packs, & real-branded trailer DLCs. However, all content is always of quality & paid content reasonably priced.

It's noteworthy that SCS [i]NEVER[/i] gives release dates for any upcoming content until 1-2 weeks from the content's launch, when they're certain beyond doubt they'll make the date they give. This is another part of what makes SCS an incredible dev. SCS also has an impressive mastery over PR & hype. E.g, map expansions. Let's use Texas. At the time of writing (08/24/2022), Texas is still in development & was announced in March 2021 as one of the next expansions. However, SCS has steadily released blogposts showing off specific cities/areas, industries, & certain industry history. They're keeping us satiated & hyped by info drops & showing development. All the way until the expansion releases. Yes, some people will forever be unhappy & complain regardless. That'll never change, but at the end of the day they'll still be here, still buy DLC, & play the game.

All this & much more is why SCS is vastly different from the rest of the gaming industry. They're down-to-Earth, very interactive w/ their community, & care deeply & passionately about their games. For SCS, their games are a labor of love.

[h3]The Game[/h3]
I've spoken at length about the dev. Let's talk about the game now. The game is exactly what the title says. A sim about trucking in America. It's not an in-depth sim like Train Sim or Microsoft Flight Sim. It's much more relaxed. A casual sim.

Looking at the game, especially if you're not wildly interested in trucking, you might think "How could trucking be fun or relaxing?" You're not alone in that. Many people thought the same, but upon trying out the demo or buying the game, many were immediately drawn in. The majority of your time spent is driving. Put on some music or a podcast & you'll be surprised at how relaxing it can be. Passing beautiful vistas, landmarks, small towns, hearing the engine roar alongside your favorite music or podcast... It's such a great experience. I admit I've found myself nearly falling asleep or actually dozed off while playing w/ music on. It's just that relaxing at times.

The game scale is 1:20 IIRC, so you reach your destination in a much shorter time than IRL. Even w/ a map mod that adds the currently missing states, or if you're playing years later from when this is written & the lower 48 is complete. If you run a load from San Diego, CA up to Bangor, ME, it'd only be maybe a 3-5 hour session. Depending if you take breaks, stop to see some sights, or take a scenic route. It's still vastly shorter than IRL. That's part of the draw. From your truck cab as you drive, you can see so much of the US in such a short amount of time & at any moment in your trip, you can park up, save & quit for a while, & come back later if a long haul is getting to be too much. Can't do that IRL.

Regarding performance/stability, the game's extremely stable in a vanilla state (Mods will obviously begin to interfere w/ performance/stability in varying degrees). The way SCS handles updates is phenomenal. S'far as I can remember, SCS has always released major updates to a Public Beta first. Anyone who owns the game can access the Public Betas if they wish to. W/ Public Beta's, there's almost never any game-breaking bugs when the update officially releases to the stable branch. This is due in part b/c they patch the bugs DURING the Betas, instead of compiling a list & doing it after it's released. You don't see many other studios do this. Even those that do something similar don't compare to the level of success SCS' Public Betas have. I honestly can't recall a single time where a fatal bug made it out of Public Beta.

Regarding mod support, the game's extremely mod-friendly. It has a Steam Workshop w/ over 8,200 mods at the time of writing. There's also mods that can be found on various mod sites. They are generally referred to as 'local mods' since they're downloaded & installed "locally" to the game's Documents folder. Though I would highly recommend using an adblocker & a solid anti-virus. Some sites people host mods on can be sketchy w/ their ads. Usually though, most good mods you can find on various sites will also be on [url=https://forum.scssoft.com/]SCS' forum[/url] where they closely monitor mods posted there. Anything you find on their forum is a pretty safe bet. Just get a good adblock & AV, browse mod sites carefully, & you'll be fine. The game has a built-in Mod Manager for both Workshop & local mods, so there's basically no end to the potential of this game w/ modding so easily accessible.

Regarding multiplayer, if you're interested in the game but don't like singleplayer, no worries. The game has built-in 8-player multiplayer w/ AI traffic called Convoy Mode. Convoy offers mod support up-to 70 active mods. Both Steam Workshop & local mods. If 8 players is too low for you & you don't mind playing the game vanilla, then there's [url=https://truckersmp.com/]TruckersMP[/url]. TruckersMP is a multiplayer mod developed by a team of people that allows MMO-style online play in ATS & ETS2. They have servers that hold a couple thousand players at once. TruckersMP, while offering higher player counts, only supports a few very specific mods & doesn't have AI traffic (At the time of writing. I'll update this IF TMP adds AI traffic). Convoy & TruckersMP have their pros & cons. Both are great in their own ways.

[h1]Review Conclusion[/h1]
I hope you found this review helpful, insightful, & detailed. I absolutely love the game. It has captured my attention for nearly the past 7 years now, & will continue to do so for many years to come. I hope it does the same for you. Strap in, load up, & hammer down!

how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
¬Ω teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ¬Ω cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

After over 500 hours of playing American Truck Simulator, I can still confidently say that it's one of the most relaxing and enjoyable games out there. Even after all this time, I still find myself coming back to it when I need to unwind and escape from the stresses of everyday life.

One of the things that has kept me playing for so long is the addition of new states over the years. When I first started playing back in 2016, there were only a handful of states to explore. But now, with the addition of several new states, the game feels even more expansive and immersive than ever before.

The graphics improvements and the addition of new trucks have also made the game shine. The level of detail on the trucks is incredible, and it's clear that the developers put a lot of time and effort into making them look and feel as realistic as possible. In fact, I was so impressed with the game that I ended up purchasing a wheel and pedals set just so I could play it more realistically.

And let me tell you, the wheel and pedals set has made a huge difference. It's like I'm actually driving a truck, and it's made the game even more enjoyable than it already was. In fact, I think playing American Truck Simulator has even helped me learn to drive a real vehicle. When I went for my first driving lesson, I was already pretty good despite it being an entirely different vehicle, especially for it not being a combination vehicle.

All in all, I would highly recommend American Truck Simulator to anyone who is looking for a relaxing and enjoyable game to play. Even after 500+ hours of playtime, it's still one of my go-to games when I need to unwind, and with all the new states and improvements that have been added over the years, it's better than ever.

American Truck Simulator (ATS) is an absolute gem for simulation enthusiasts and trucking fans alike. As someone who's spent countless hours on the virtual roads of ATS, I can confidently say that it offers an incredibly immersive and enjoyable experience.

First and foremost, the attention to detail in ATS is nothing short of astounding. The game's depiction of American landscapes, cities, and highways is remarkably realistic, making each journey feel like a real road trip across the United States. The graphics are stunning, and the day-night cycle and weather effects add depth to the visuals.

The truck models are beautifully rendered, and you can customize your rig to your heart's content, from the paint job to the cabin interior. The engine sounds are satisfyingly authentic, making you feel like you're actually behind the wheel of a big rig. The controls are intuitive and responsive, whether you prefer using a keyboard and mouse or a dedicated steering wheel setup.

One of ATS's standout features is its vast map, which covers various American states and keeps expanding with DLCs. Each state has its own unique charm and challenges, ensuring that no two trips are the same. The job market offers a wide variety of cargo types and destinations, allowing you to tailor your trucking career to your liking. You can choose to transport everything from heavy machinery to fragile goods.

The AI traffic and pedestrian behavior have improved significantly over time, making the roads feel more alive and dynamic. The traffic rules and regulations are faithfully simulated, adding an extra layer of realism. You'll need to obey speed limits, use your turn signals, and rest at regular intervals to avoid fatigue.

Multiplayer mode is another highlight of ATS, allowing you to team up with friends or other players for an even more enjoyable trucking experience. Convoys, competitions, and collaborative missions make multiplayer a great addition to the game.

Overall, American Truck Simulator is a meticulously crafted simulation game that offers a perfect blend of realism and fun. Whether you're a trucking enthusiast or just looking for a relaxing and immersive gaming experience, ATS has something to offer. With regular updates, a dedicated modding community, and a roadmap for future expansions, ATS continues to evolve and improve, ensuring that your trucking adventures will never get old. Highly recommended! ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

American Truck Simulator is a surprisingly immersive and visually stunning journey through the heartland of America. From the meticulously detailed trucks to the diverse landscapes of each state, the game effortlessly captures the essence of the open road. The career mode offers a satisfying progression system, allowing players to start as a lone driver and work their way up to building a trucking empire. The realistic handling of the trucks, coupled with the ambient sounds and well-curated radio stations, creates an authentic and enjoyable driving experience. Whether you're a simulation enthusiast or just seeking a relaxing virtual road trip, American Truck Simulator delivers a satisfying and engaging ride.

American Truck Simulator is a gem for those seeking a unique and immersive experience in the world of simulation games. From the serene landscapes to the attention to detail in truck mechanics, this game offers a relaxing yet engaging journey through the heartland of the United States.

First and foremost, the graphics in American Truck Simulator are nothing short of breathtaking. The meticulously crafted environments capture the essence of diverse American landscapes, from the sun-soaked highways of California to the snow-covered roads of Oregon. The day-night cycles and weather effects add a level of realism that enhances the overall visual experience.

The driving mechanics are spot-on, providing a satisfying blend of realism and accessibility. Maneuvering a massive truck through bustling city streets or cruising down long, winding highways feels both challenging and rewarding. The inclusion of realistic trucking elements, such as fuel management and rest stops, adds an extra layer of immersion to the gameplay.

The variety of trucks available is a notable highlight. Each vehicle feels distinct, offering a range of options for players to choose from based on their preferences and the cargo they're hauling. The customization options, from paint jobs to interior accessories, allow for a personal touch that adds to the sense of ownership and connection with your virtual rig.

The open-world exploration aspect of American Truck Simulator is where the game truly shines. The freedom to choose your routes, take on diverse jobs, and explore iconic landmarks creates a sense of adventure. The inclusion of realistic traffic and road signage further enhances the immersive experience, making you feel like a true trucker navigating the highways.

The game's support for mods adds a layer of replayability, with a vibrant community constantly contributing new trucks, maps, and features. The developer's commitment to updates and improvements also ensures that the game continues to evolve, keeping players engaged over the long haul.

In conclusion, American Truck Simulator delivers a tranquil yet captivating journey through the American landscape. Whether you're a truck enthusiast or someone looking for a unique and relaxing gaming experience, this title is a must-have. So, buckle up, hit the road, and enjoy the scenic beauty and challenges that American Truck Simulator has to offer.

The best simulation game I've ever played.

It maintains a good balance of realism and quality-of-life features, and is good to pick up, play for a while, and then come back to it later.

I used to think this game was kinda cringe. I'd see it (and its sibling Euro Truck Simulator) pop up in my Steam recommendations occasionally, and I'd always ignore it. But someone dared me to try it, and so here I am, nearly 300 hours of gameplay later, wholeheartedly recommending others buy and enjoy this game.

You haven't lived until you've gotten an articulated load up to 80+ MPH, swerved to avoid a construction zone, gone off the road, back onto the road, jacknifed into a pretzel, and clipped through the ground, falling into the void until you reload from last save.

This game is *NOT* glitchy, not even a little bit. Which makes my above experience all the more entertaining. Also, it auto-saves often enough that you're not really punished for screwing up that badly, which is nice and relaxing.

And the developer keeps churning out more and more really well-made content, which is awesome. Nothing here is schlock, and it's nowhere near as "cringe" as it seemed to be at first.

I will simply put it this way, if you enjoy driving aroung because it's relaxing, Then this will be the best game to play because it will be relaxing to drive in the confort of you home plus you will  get to know landscapes that you never knew before..... Highly recommended !!!

Well, folks.  Here we are.  The Hype is real and still is!

I bought ATS as it is called by players because I loved ETS2 and wanted to play an American Truck game, like the old 18 WoS days.  So far, I'm not disappointed by the game one bit.  

Yeah, you only get two trucks at the start, and I'm fine with that.  The reasoning for the lack of immediate content is actually a good one for once.  It is because rather than put fake brands in the game, SCS wants to get licenses first.  But, as said by Pavel Sebor himself, getting licenses from truck manufacurers that aren't used to being approached for licenses of their product is like the chicken vs egg debate.  So, they are going about it the right way at least.

On to the gameplay.  Those of you that are familiar with ETS2 will have no problem getting used to the ATS Gameplay.  There are a lot of new things to compliment to already very good base gameplay that I hope will be making it's way to ETS2 soon as well.  

Delivery Points are the biggest advancement in the gameplay system.  You can choose how difficult you want the delivery to be.  From a zero point quick drop to a 90 point drop that is so complex, even the most Veteran Driver will have a challenge are available for choosing.

Weigh Stations are new to the game.  You can be randomly chosen to go to the Scale House for Inspection.  It's an interesting feature, but a bit of a waste of time and ruins fuel economy.  Hopefully, SCS will be able to do something to give this feature more meaning.

After talking about weigh stations, we have no choice but to talk about the new police engine.  Now, the dreaded Rozzers are mobile and sneaky.  I got a Speeding Ticket for not being at 30 MPH right after the sign changed.  There needs to be a Reduced Speed Ahead sign, like in real life here in the States.

So, lets break it down to the Pros and Cons.

Pros

Familiar yet tweaked Gameplay
American Trucks
Nevada included 
Scenery that will blow your mind
Easter Eggs, yes, there a few, and no, I will not tell you what they are
No curves every 20 feet like ETS2


Cons

Only two states at the beginning
Only two trucks at the beginning,  Not really a con, but may put some people off
The UI is completely Copy/Paste.  Would have loved to see the Route Adviser remodeled.  Maybe next time.
Only 64-Bit
  

Having looked at the facts and played a long time, I can give a solid 9 out of 10.  This game is definitely worth a buy.  It's continued development is something I look forward to.


UPDATE:  W900 is out and it's not bad.  The sounds need a little tweaking still, but at least it's there.


UPDATE 2:  It's 2023 and ATS is light years ahead of where it was at last review update.  In the last seven years, ATS has went from an American-skinned ETS2 to a grand, yet still unfinished Epic of American trucking.  So much more content has been released over the years.  SCS has kept on improving both games, especially ATS.  Trucks, Trailers, and Maps all continue to get better with every update.  I'm over 6000 Hours in as of this update.  I see many more thousands of hours of game play ahead for me with ATS.  It's become beyond just a game.  It has become a reliable, old friend that I enjoy engaging with nearly every day, despite some of the frustrations it causes me from time to time.

I like simulation games but driving a truck?
Surprisingly it is very relaxing and provides a steady challenge without being impossibly difficult.  It has also given me a greater appreciation of just how dumb car drivers can be when dealing with big rigs.
The constant updates are great and I look forward to each new area release and not coming from the US it helps me learn a bit more about the country, though it would be nice to have more detail about the states that you drive through in game and better markings in the map as due to the necessary time compression in the game (who would really want to drive in real time?  right?) you can skip through areas pretty quickly and not realise when you have crossed state borders. It's actually a very fun and relaxing game to play. Wasn't sure if I was really gone like or love it but to be honest I actually do. The game may not have the best of the best graphics but it makes it up with having a great gameplay. Personally I always prefer gameplay over graphics, I mean a tree may look super realistic but I don't spend hours looking at it.
Some people may find that the game becomes boring after a while because all you sort of do is transport goods from point A to point B. I'm not gone argue with that because it is literally transporting goods and items from point A to point B, but for me it never got boring (atleast not yet), or maybe that's because I play it for several hours for several days and then I leave the game alone again for several days.

During 2023 we received several new expansions to the map (Oklahoma & Kansas) and I must say, the bigger the map becomes the better the game becomes. This may sound strange but it's really how I feel about it, partially because the map get's more diverse and als more interesting to drive around in.

Anyways I would recommend this game.

Relaxing sim with plenty of progress as you can buy and upgrade your own trucks, trailers, and garages as you expand your business. Best played with a steering wheel and foot pedals for maximum immersion. There are community events that help foster this rather wholesome community.

DLCs are regularly released that can add new jobs, trucks, and states that can help expand the game.

Very relaxing, enjoyable game. Its a bit of a grind and your workers do not generate a lot of money at first, however, over time they do start to make enough to cover loans if you choose to go down that path. There are many different ways to start off the game, I noticed a good way to make money and stay debt free is to just complete jobs until you have  enough to buy your first truck. Then I focused primarily on heavy cargo since it tends to pay the most. Either long distance, or most dollar per mile is the way to go. If you like to drive and explore the painstakingly detailed environment, I recommend long distance. You do not need the DLC's to have a good time, however I would implore you to purchase them to add to the detail and amazing experiences of the game. The developers take great care of listening to the fans and making great content.

My foray into the trucking simulation world like many started with the 18 Wheels of Steel (18WOS) series.  Which was also developed by SCS.  

American Truck Simulator is a follow up game based on the same game engine used by Euro Truck Simulator 2 (ETS2).  ATS is in a very early state of development with a few states from which you can drive through as well as just a few licensed trucks to choose as your daily driver.  However as with many simulation style games, mods are what really makes the game shine.  

The vanilla game is very enjoyable in it's "As-Is" state.  But as you add mods and start re-skinning your truck to a look that fits your style.  The simulation feel will start to shine.  

Also as with many simulation style games it comes down to how you want to play the game.  There are many in-game options for this simulator that you can turn on and off to suit your style.  There are third parties who are creating add-ons that like many driving-style simulators will give that realistic feeling for driving.  An  SKRS-style shifter is one such add-on as well as button boxes to give that more in cabin feel an example is the A.S.P. box.  Add those 2 items with a steering/driving wheel with pedals and shifter and if you have the cash for one a gaming cockpit.  Now if you are like myself and currently on a limited budget the keyboard/joystick/game pad are more then enough for many hours of truck driving enjoyment. 

Latest updates and dlc to the game have added heavy hauls, double trailers and another state, New Mexico.

Special Transport and the addition of Oregon continues to expand the experience of the this game and adds more variety for your hauls.

Forest Machinery DLC and Washington state now completes the west coast and now we can keep our eyes open to the east.

Utah continues the ever expanding journey towards the east coast.  SCS also has added Volvo trucks.  This expands the game quite a bit and offers even more for the vanilla game.

Idaho continues the lower 48 expansion.

Colorado, Wyoming, Montana and the most anticipated state of Texas has been added as well putting the game map at the middle of the United States.

Also two new trucks join the line up and they are the International Lone Star and the Mack Anthem. 

Western Star truck 49x joins the line up.
November 2020 with the release of Colorado.  The map continues it's progression towards the east.

The Volvo VNL was recently added.

Convoy mode added to allow you and 7 friends to drive together and now mods are allowed with Convoy mode as well.

 My final thoughts on this game.  If you are looking to drive across the lower 48, this is quite a ways away before this will become a reality.  However if you have ever modded a game with a few mods this will take this game to a different level for many and be a welcomed addition to a driving enthusiasts gaming collection.
The game is fun and all

I loved driving coast-to-coast in the real USA and I don't think that feat will ever be repeated. So this is the second best thing (or will be when the contiguous 48 states are completed). But for now, it's terrific fun to travel the west coast and mountain states and see the fantastic scenery.

I commend the developers for their work in 2023, we will have had two more states added but I shudder to think there's potentially another ten years to go before most of the country is complete!

American Truck Simulator is the epitome of a road trip fantasy, offering an immersive and authentic experience of life on the open highways. As a virtual semi-truck driver navigating the vast landscapes of the United States, this simulator brings a unique blend of relaxation and challenge.

The attention to detail in American Truck Simulator is nothing short of remarkable. From the iconic landmarks to the realistic weather conditions, every element contributes to the sense of actually traversing the diverse terrains of the U.S. The meticulously crafted environments make each journey a visually stunning and enjoyable experience.

What truly sets this simulator apart is the dedication of its development team. The commitment to delivering a realistic and evolving experience is evident in the constant stream of updates and State DLCs. The addition of new states keeps the game fresh and expands the already expansive virtual road network.

The sense of immersion is heightened by the realistic driving mechanics and the attention given to the little details, such as the changing day-night cycle and the diverse array of cargo to haul. Whether you're a trucking enthusiast or a casual gamer looking for a relaxing yet engaging experience, American Truck Simulator delivers on all fronts.

In conclusion, American Truck Simulator is more than just a game; it's a journey across the heart of the United States. The dedication of the development team ensures that the road ahead is filled with exciting possibilities. If you've ever dreamed of hitting the open road in a big rig, this simulator is a must-play, offering a satisfying and ever-expanding road trip experience.

Needless to say, American Truck Simulator is a wonderful game and SCS Software is the example of a good developers. They usually update their game and add a new DLCs. I dunno, how I coulda liked those DLCs, which I haven't bought yet. Now I've only a three DLCs for map: Washington, Oregon and Idaho. I really appreciate 'em. I started my acquaintance with ATS at 2019th when I was visiting at my aunt and husband of her daughter showed me the American Truck Simulator. I was 11 and I was dreaming to play ATS. It was awesome for me coz I like American trucks: they're big, angry and powerful! I also like American nature, particularly the palms in the California and spruces in the Washington. I know that trucks in the ETS 2 lot more powerful and nature of ETS 2 more various too with the all DLCs. But I don't like Euro trucks as well as I like American trucks. It's a matter of taste. I don't remember how many trucks's models being in this game, but I know, that that's a big amount. 
VIBE: It's not the most important aspect in a game such this. But if compare it with the ETS 2, vibe in the ATS and in the ETS 2 are different. It's a vibe of long highways, dangerous and narrow roads through the big mountains. It's dangerous particularly on the big American trucks! Ya can't compare soundtrack in the main menu in the American Truck Simulator and in the Euro Truck Simulator 2. It's a wonderful sound! 
PHYSICS: You can evaluate a physics in a simulator just if you know, how it happens in the real world. How can you understand, I haven't driven a real truck, particularly an American. That's why I can't evaluate the physics in the ATS. I let a real driver write about the ATSs physics in the comments. 
TUNING: I've heard any driver can tune their own car however want in the USA. And if it's truth, SCS made a realistic detail in its game. At least you have enough paint jobs to tune your truck to it looks like a normal truck even without any DLCs for paint jobs. But if ya wanna you can buy one DLC for your wish and tune your truck. ATS hasn't a big variety of customization of individual parts like the NFS Carbon but it has enough. Long story short tuning in the ATS is made qualitatively. 
MAP: Map and nature of the roads pretty various at this game. California is a long state with a long, straight highways and the palms. Washington is the small state which full of the mountains and spruces. Every state differs from the other states. It's great and I'mma buy the Utah and Colorado at the next summer. 
TRUCKS: Diversity of the trucks is a big. So, you can find a 7 truck manufacturers and 14 models(I found out this information in the internet, before I didn't know it)! It seems to me you will find your truck. For Instance, I like Mack Anthem. 
RPG: ATS is a RPG game to some extent. You can don't develop your company, buy hundreds of trucks without recruit your drivers, but you can if you want to. 
To sum up, I like ATS and periodically play to it. If you're looking for a game, which pretty easy to chill out or a game where you can see a beautiful American nature, American Truck Simulator is the game for you! 
Good luck on the roads!

I love the fact that this game gives you the experiences of being a truck driver, you can either drive for a company or buy trucks and trailers and create your own loads all over. Experience the Interstate Highways, having to refuel and sleep every now n then, also if you desire to, you can customize your trucks and trailers as well.  I love the realism it brings, everything you do can make or break you, if you choose to park the trailer in a simple pull up drop off or back it up like a real truck driver or skip both if you wish.  

The game also has lots of content to add to it too, nice map expansion DLCs so you can play with a bigger map than what's given from the start, add Cargo and Paintjob DLCs to add more character to the game and have fun, but it also has a bank system in here too where you get loans if you wish, i personally do not go for loans or those Infinite money mods because i like the feeling of grinding and working for what i want rather than just cheat and buy it.

Recommended? Yes if you are a real trucker. No, if you are not. YES, if you only seek to explore the western US. Frankly, they should just call this US Western Truck Simulator instead of AMERICAN Truck simulator since it only consists of all the states in the WESTERN US only and nothing in the Eastern or Central US. Worst more, it does not even consist of ALASKA and cross country like Crossing to Canada to get to Alaska and back. Pretty sad really.

The game is fun, but the lack of the other US states is just...disheartening. I want to drive in my  home state Alaska and St Louis Missouri or even Chicago, IL and Atlanta, GA or Jacksonville, FL.  Trust me, I'm a real trucker. 

Another disadvantage? It severely lacks on the training part. There is no trucking school or anything like teaching you to maneuver a trailer with cones and stuff. They just put you at a random site, tell you a few controls, and just call it done from there. It's sad. Why not add a Trucking School DLC or something eh? Endorsements simulator? It's fun still, but sad.
